p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 16th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 9 August 2023, 6 September 2023, and 13 September 2023.
1. The committee resolved to present the
following 54 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 107 petitioners—requesting the cessation of the 2023 Australian Indigenous Voice referendum (EN5331)
From 12 petitioners—requesting that businesses be banned from adding surcharges on non-cash transactions (EN5358)
From 23 petitioners—requesting that flea, tick, and heartworm products containing isoxazolines be classified as Schedule 4 items on the Poisons Standard (EN5359)

From 11 petitioners—requesting amendment of Section 140A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 to allow for development of nuclear fusion energy (EN5360)

From 4 petitioners—requesting amendment of Section 140A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 to allow for development of nuclear fusion energy (EN5361)

From 4 petitioners—requesting amendment of Section 140A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 to allow for development of nuclear fusion energy (EN5364)

From 3 petitioners—requesting amendment of Section 140A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 to allow for development of nuclear fusion energy (EN5365)

From 12 petitioners—requesting amendment of Section 140A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 to allow for development of nuclear fusion energy (EN5366)

From 1 petitioner—requesting amendment of Section 140A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 to allow for development of nuclear fusion energy (EN5367)
From 21 petitioners—requesting removal of the automatic indexation on excise duty rates for commercially produced alcohol (EN5368)
From 33 petitioners—requesting that the processing times for the offshore partner visas 300 and 309 be reduced (EN5370)
From 3 petitioners—regarding acts of violence committed against Indian Muslims (EN5372)
From 234 petitioners—regarding the expansion of access to antiviral treatments for people suffering health problems associated with long COVID (EN5373)
From 11 petitioners—regarding ongoing human rights violations and undemocratic activities in Bangladesh (EN5376)
From 2 petitioners—requesting the investigation of VETASSESS processing times (EN5377)
From 4 petitioners—requesting that the i-Port Advance™ be covered under the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS) (EN5378)
From 54 petitioners—requesting the investigation of possible unfair decisions under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (EN5380)
From 13 petitioners—requesting regulations to replace folic acid with folate in common daily foods (EN5381)
From 6 petitioners—requesting changes to the cap on spousal income in the Disability Support Pension (DSP) income test (EN5382)
From 531 petitioners—requesting the incorporation of a Bill of Rights into the Australian Constitution (EN5383)
From 52 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a Royal Commission into Australian Federal and State Governments' responses to the COVID-19 pandemic (EN5385)
From 116 petitioners—requesting legislation to guarantee reasonable access to banking services and physical cash for all Australians (EN5391)
From 813 petitioners—regarding violence in Manipur and the protection of Christians and minorities in India (EN5392)
From 4649 petitioners—requesting a rejection of any proposals for the development of an offshore wind zone near Port MacDonnell (EN5394)
From 34 petitioners—requesting funding for Pacific Island cultural hubs in major states where large Pacific Islander communities reside (EN5395)
From 131 petitioners—requesting the introduction of 10 days paid menstrual leave for working women in Australia (EN5396)
From 117 petitioners—requesting amendment to provisions of the Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Payment under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 to (EN5397)
From 193 petitioners—regarding regulation of Event Data Recorders in vehicles (EN5398)
From 1405 petitioners—requesting the closure of the Russian Consulate in Sydney and the expulsion of its diplomatic staff (EN5399)
From 69 petitioners—requesting that the proposed Illawarra Offshore Windfarm be rejected (EN5402)
From 14 petitioners—requesting cooperation with the Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification to include residential cleaning companies in worker compensation schemes (EN5403)
From 206 petitioners—requesting the establishment of a national wildlife patrol service to protect native wildlife (EN5408)
From 2 petitioners—requesting the introduction of a program to educate the Australian public on the structure and functions of the executive branch of government (EN5409)
From 13 petitioners—requesting that greater restrictions be placed on lobbyists' access to Parliament House (EN5411)
From 66 petitioners—requesting that no new COVID-19 restrictions be legislated, and requesting that the House oppose any new state restrictions (EN5416)
From 510 petitioners—regarding wait times for onshore applicants applying for a 491 or 494 visa while on a bridging visa or responding to a s56 request (EN5417)
From 21 petitioners—requesting that the House introduce and pass legislation to establish separate referenda for Constitutional recognition and the Voice (EN5419)
From 31 petitioners—regarding the AEC's Ballot Paper Formality Guidelines
for the upcoming referendum (EN5421)
From 477 petitioners—requesting that the terms of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission investigation and enforcement inquiry be expanded to include the ACCC's activities (EN5423)
From 17 petitioners—requesting an acknowledgement of the contributions of the First Fleet and European settlers in the Australian Constitution (EN5427)
From 9 petitioners—requesting that imported products in Australia be required to have a label displaying total carbon emissions involved in production and importation (EN5428)
From 51 petitioners—requesting the addition of freedom of speech into the Australian Constitution (EN5429)
From 7 petitioners—requesting legislation that enables men to enact a financial abortion (EN5430)
From 21 petitioners—requesting the introduction of reforms to mitigate the effects of bullying in Australian schools (EN5433)
From 20 petitioners—requesting an immediate ban on harmful and explicit content in Australia (EN5435)
From 16 petitioners—requesting an end to the live export of animals (EN5439)
From 28 petitioners—requesting a Royal Commission into the housing and rental crisis (EN5440)
From 15 petitioners—regarding the introduction of a new federal government body to audit and investigate rental properties and real estate agents (EN5441)
From 788 petitioners—requesting a moratorium on offshore wind projects in Australia (EN5442)
From 32 petitioners—requesting an end to the live export of animals
From 42 petitioners—requesting the legalisation of capital punishment for convicted paedophiles (EN5445)
From 212 petitioners—regarding reforms to existing childcare legislation to prevent discrimination against children with profound disabilities (EN5446)
From 11147 petitioners—requesting amendment to visa options for parents of Australian children who are citizens (EN5447)
From 10 petitioners—requesting that volunteer work be included as specified work for the 88-day requirement for visa holders seeking to extend their stay (EN5448)

From the Minister for Communications to a petition regarding the concentration of media ownership across newspapers, radio and television (EN4258)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting the ban on online poker be removed (EN4274)
From the Minister for Education to a petition regarding the legitimacy of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) system (EN4332)
From the Minister for Sport to a petition requesting the establishment of a national motorsport strategy (EN4392)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting increased support for carers of elderly Australians (EN4403)
From the Attorney-General to a petition regarding the legalisation of cannabis for personal use and the creation of a regulatory system (EN4411)
From the Minister for Early Childhood Education to a petition requesting the Child Care Subsidy (CCS) be extended to grandparents who look after their grandchildren (EN4430)

From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition requesting changes to the proposed Inland Rail line to bypass Wagga Wagga's Central Business District (EN4453)
From the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister to a petition requesting that the Australian Government establish a national public holiday to honour the late Queen Elizabeth II's memory (EN4468)
From the Assistant Treasurer to a petition regarding the Australian Taxation Office's handling of GST liabilities (EN4657)
From the Assistant Treasurer to a petition requesting the introduction of legislation for companies to enable consumers to unsubscribe from their services (EN4697)
From the Attorney-General to a petition regarding the retention and protection of personal information by companies (EN4968)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting a ban on gambling advertising on all Australian media (EN4998)
From the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations to a petition requesting a ban on junior rates of pay (EN5023)
From the Attorney-General to a petition regarding the proposed implementation of a national firearms register (EN5026)
From the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations to a petition requesting an amendment to the Fair Work Act 2009 to regulate job advertisements (EN5030)
From the Minister for Emergency Management to a petition requesting a resilience package for Cabonne, New South Wales (EN5065)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting the review and limiting of the proliferation of certain Indian Hindutva films (EN5113)
From the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition regarding the funding of a stadium at Macquarie Point, Hobart (EN5143)
From the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations to a petition requesting that wages be linked to the Consumer Price Index or RBA cash rate (EN5150)
From the Minister for Housing to a petition requesting that funding for the National Rental Affordability Scheme be extended (EN5165)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding the situation in Nagorno-Karabakh (EN5210)
From the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to a petition requesting the removal of the biosecurity levy for Australian farmers (EN5214)
From the Minister for Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government to a petition regarding the funding for the Gold Coast Light Rail Stage 4 (EN5216)
From the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a petition requesting amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 in response to a Federal Court decision (EN5220)
From the Minister for Early Childhood Education to a petition regarding wages and conditions for early childhood educators and teachers (PN0547)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 54 petitions:

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice
Waste of money running a referendum to achieve a result that can be achieved without one. The likely outcome resulting a negative result for First People.

We therefore ask the House to cease preparations to hold a referendum on "A Proposed Law: to alter the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice", aka "The Voice", be ceased immediately. I call for this not in the cause of discrimination, racism, divisiveness, or any other reason apart from, the fact, that it is unnecessary and an unprecedented waste of taxpayer's money. A "Voice" can be created without a change to the constitution. Referendums are only required when the constitution does not permit the passage of a law, "The Voice" can be created without an expensive change in The Constitution and is unnecessary.

This should happen as a matter of urgency so that an alternate referendum that recognises Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in The Constitution can be conceived and implemented within an achievable time frame. I believe that the majority of Australians support the recognition of the recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander in the constitution and it would be an utter travesty if this were not to occur due to a misguided, unnecessary, expensive, construction.
It appears as though many in the current parliament do not understand the machinery of government. We call for a demonstration of competence from our government.
from 107 citizens (Petition No. EN5331)
Banking and Financial Services

Australia has done incredibly well on reducing the utilization of cash over the number of years, however its going wrong on allowing businesses to pass electronic transaction costs in the form of Surcharge back to consumers.

Each transaction is becoming costlier by 1.5%-2.00% on average, demotivating consumers to pay by e-POS. In fact, I've come across business offering customers 5% discount on the bill for paying by cash. Cash is a cost to the taxpayer. Cash is a way of avoiding declaring full revenue and reducing tax. Cash creates physical security risks for both users and receivers. In Europe Surcharging is completely banned for these and many other reasons.

E-pos is just part of the cost of doing business, the RBA should not regulate these costs be passed on to consumers. By that virtue, there is on average a 2% cost associated to print, transport and manage notes, why not pass that cost on to cash users too?

We therefore ask the House to request the RBA to ban/disallow surcharging on non-cash transactions of all types. Consumers should not be passed on the cost of businesses deciding to accept electronic payments. It should be a commercial decision that each business should take based on what they deem is best for them rather than pushing the society into using cash, and penalizing them for not using it.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5358)
Veterinary Medicines

Currently flea, tick and heartworm products are available for purchase without a prescription. This can be dangerous for some pets as their health status needs to be assessed by a veterinarian before using these products. For example, flea and tick products containing isoxazolines should be used with caution on sick, debilitated or underweight animals and animals with a history of seizures. Also animals should be tested for adult heartworm infection before being giving heartworm preventatives as they don't actually kill adult heartworms. If already infected animals can spread the disease even when they are on heartworm preventatives.

We therefore ask the House to direct the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) to classify flea and tick products containing isoxazolines as Schedule 4 items on the Poisons Standard. We also ask the House to direct the APVMA to classify heartworm preventatives as Schedule 4 items on the Poisons Standard. Additionally, we ask the House to direct the APVMA to put the following warnings on the front of the packaging of these products—Use with caution on sick, debilitated or underweight animals, Use with caution on animals with a history of seizures and Test for adult heartworm infection before using this product.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN5359)
Nuclear Energy

To allocate funding of $500 million to develope a fusion energy industry in Australia similiar to the the US, UK and EU and would be regulated similiar as in the United States under a similar regulatory regime as particle accelerators, and as in the UK government as they will legislate to make clear in law the regulatory treatment of fusion energy. This provides certainty and confidence to the industry by amending the law which to date excludes fusion energy facilities as in present nuclear regulatory and licensing requirements. To have the government also initiate legislative changes and the assessment of the hazard of fusion energy facilities and the significant difference to nuclear fission power plants. This petition is now requesting the putting in place formal actions and programs to develop standards and controls to develop areas of the Australian regulatory framework and the associated legislation internationally required and agreed on and in line with Australia. This petition, in line with advancing and developing Australian manufacturing and technology, will also be developing new pathways for jobs, and education and helping with increasing our export trade.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and bring the legislation in line with the US and UK Nuclear Fusion Initiatives and maintain a moratorium on Nuclear Fission.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5360)
Nuclear Energy
Is the House aware of the urgent need to develop Nuclear fusion?

Reports to government miss the real world "Not without your approval: a way forward for nuclear technology in Australia & the senate's tables on the 11 Aug 2023 Environment and Other Legislation Amendment (Removing Nuclear Energy Prohibitions) Bill 2022 &Defence Legislation Amendment (Naval Nuclear Propulsion) Bill 2023 [Provisions]"?

The US and the UK already enacted laws during this time to separate Fission and Fusion and to free Fusion from the constraints of nuclear legislation that obstruct its development and acceptance. Why hasn't the government provided funds to sciences, education, and industry to create businesses and employment, to progress and acknowledgment its safety and significance and trade with S.E. Asian region?

Where's a fusion dialogue on sovereignty and security with them? FIA announced a future energy source available from the 2030s. Known to be the option safer than nuclear fission, with no radiological waste.
Australia's government funded offshore development with the HB11 group in this industry or invested substantially in any other Nuclear Fusion research?
OUR future is without Fission energy for electricity, ships, space, defence, or planes.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy start Australia down the path of setting up the regulatory framework needed for the nuclear fusion power industry development in Australia.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5361)
Nuclear Energy

A grant was given to assist this Australian company from the federal government, to provide proof-of-concept and further development of new petawatt laser technology that is suited to generating hydrogen-boron fusion.
I congratulate the government on taking these vital first steps toward the development of a future Australian Nuclear Fusion Industry Excluding Nuclear Fission.
It will be a quantum leap in energy, sovereign security, industrial, manufacturing, and possible future world energy leadership.

Except for that, the company has to move its manufacturing and development offshore to Spain. This shows the general short-sightedness of the government and its advisors who didn't advise of changes needed in legislation to keep this leading international company on Australian soil. This is a major energy and environmental industry loss to Australia if it is continued to happen.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5364)
Nuclear Energy

Investment in the global fusion industry has now reached a cumulative USD6.21 billion, up from USD4.8 billion a year ago, according to the third annual Global Fusion Industry Report from the Fusion Industry Association. The report surveyed 43 private fusion companies, up from 27 a year earlier.

The Australian people need the government to invest in this industry and change legislation to allow it to happen on our own continent you are letting the space agency decline and the energy sector becomes untenable do not miss this opportunity to help create jobs, develop new technologies and lead again in a discovery of an Australian citizen.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5365)
Nuclear Energy

Environment and Other Legislation Amendment (Removing Nuclear Energy Prohibitions) Bill 2022, should not be accepted nor seen as a good research of information as it is biased and poorly investigated. They failed to allow themselves not to be properly informed on nuclear fission or nuclear fusion. They failed to take advantage of any overseas research or conferences on both fission and fusion and site inspections of working or decommissioning nuclear fission and fusion sites around the world and their various research facilities. They have allowed themselves to be blinkered by the Australian nuclear fission industry which will promote itself at the cost of Australia as a safer and cleaner energy source. The Australian nuclear industry is biased toward fission and fails to get tertiary education to separate nuclear into fission and fusion campuses.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5366)
Nuclear Energy
China / Science
Thailand debuts the first tokamak with the help of Chinese scientists in a milestone for Southeast Asia's clean energy research.
The Australian government needs to invest in Nuclear fusion development to balance SE Asian Domaanace by China

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN5367)
Taxation
The automatic excise increases on alcohol place added pressure on inflation.
They create pressure in industries that provide 100000's of jobs.

It threatens the social fabric of the great Australian get together an encouraged people to look for other outlets that may not have the compliance and duty of care pressures that the alcohol industry has.
We therefore ask the House to change the legislation to remove the automatic excise (tax) increases on alcohol.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN5368)
Partner Visas
Processing times are too long when often these cases are straightforward and should have priority since we are living apart from our partners.
We therefore ask the House to really pay attention to the huge delay in processing offshore partner visas, both 300 and 309.

Delays have cause not only mental but financial strain in couples. Plans have been put on hold, relationships have broken down, the mental weight sometimes is to much to bear where people often even think about taking their own lives.

The department of home affairs does not provide any useful answers, I think is discriminatory that just because we have partners offshore we have to suffer the huge delays in making a decision that in most cases is straightforward. The lack of empathy, accountability and efficiency from the department is appalling and all they say is things are getting better, when they are actually not.

We do ask for firm and certain action regarding these long processing times and to have some empathy for us Australian citizens that are struggling to get by due to the mental, physical and financial burden they we have to carry to be able to carry on with a long distance relationship.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN5370)
Human Rights: India

India is home to some 200 million Muslims who make up the predominantly Hindu country's largest minority group. The last week reported acts of violence through-out India including hate speeches against Muslims, brutal killing of three innocent Muslims passenger last week by Indian railways police constable who was seen praising current Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi extreme policies against Muslims while committing heinous killing, 450 worshippers Mosque in Gurugram was burnt to ashes and 22 year old young Imam was lynched and brutally killed, NUH district in Haryana state administration has been demolishing houses and shops belonging to Muslims are few example of atrocities happened against Indian Muslims either by Hindu far-right mob or Indian state administration itself which have caused distress among global citizens who value human rights and equality for all.

Furthermore, the World Press Freedom Index ranking India 161 out of 180 is deeply troubling. Press freedom is a fundamental pillar of democracy, and its erosion can lead to the spread of misinformation, propaganda, and the promotion of divisive ideologies. In 2024 India is going for nationwide federal election, it is very unfortunate that majority of Indian media are alleged in promoting a far-right Hindu political agenda praising current government policies which target Muslims and creating an atmosphere of Islamophobia, which has led to above mentioned violence.
We therefore ask the House to raise our voice in Australian Parliament as Australia's unwavering commitment to uphold human rights and inclusivity sets an example for nations across the world.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5372)
Long COVID

Long Covid is a prevalent chronic condition that is disabling up to 5-10% of the population who contract Covid-19. It manifests in up to 200 debilitating symptoms including fatigue, pain, respiratory issues, cardiovascular issues, cognitive dysfunction, sleep issues and gastrointestinal issues, among many others.

People who have long covid are extremely vulnerable to their already crippling condition being worsened by repeat infections. Gavi, the Global Vaccine Alliance conducted a study of 596 participants with Long Covid. The results showed that 80% of participants who still had long covid at the time of reinfection saw their symptoms worsen, whilst 60% of people in remission from Long Covid had a re-emerging symptoms (Gavi, 2022).
The worsening of symptoms can have devastating effects of Long Covid sufferers; physically, emotionally, socially & financially .

Long Covid suffers deserve to be officially entitled to priority access to antiviral treatment for Covid reinfection. This would help to prevent the worsening of their condition, caused by the same virus that made them sick in the first place.
We therefore ask the House to officially list Long Covid as an eligible condition in order to gain access to antiviral treatments for repeated infections under the PBS at the earliest time.
from 234 citizens (Petition No. EN5373)
Bangladesh
1. There are plenty of torture, extra-judicial killings, political persecution, wrongful imprisonment and the forced disappearance of members and supporters of the Opposition.
2. The political crisis in Bangladesh has destabilised the country and created fear among Bangladesh citizens whose democratic right to support the Opposition is being suppressed.
We therefore ask the House to take all appropriate measures to call on the Bangladesh Government to-
1. immediately release former Prime Minister Begum Khaleda Zia and other members and supporters of the Opposition;
2. address the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Bangladesh;
3. uphold proper democratic and judicial processes; and
4. Hold a free and fair election under the auspices of a neutral authority.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5376)
Skilled Migration

Vetassess currently has a 20 week processing time for skills assessments which is impacting not only the lives of people currently in Australia but also those looking to move here. We have a huge requirement for staff but re completely stuck due to their inability to process applications efficiently. The priority process is also rigged, previously with bots and now with the system not working correctly resulting in many people being pushed to the back of the queue who applied before others.

This needs to change so it becomes a fair process and doesn't deter people from moving to Australia. If they cannot handle the workload, then instruct a second company. It is not fair to make the individual suffer.

We therefore ask the House to investigate Vetassess and their ability to perform the task they have been allocated to perform in a timely manner. Failing this we ask the house to instruct a secondary option in order to speed up the process.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5377)
Diabetes
Needles are painful . These are a great solution for newly diagnosed people and also long term diabetics.
We therefore ask the House to please put iports on the NDSS.
These are painless devices for injections.
Insulin dependent diabetics have to inject multiple times a day. Iports are currently 90 dollars for 10. Please make these free for diabetics like needles on the ndss.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5378)
Veterans

In 2020 the Department of Veterans' Affairs recognised the reason for decision templates delegates of the Repatriation Commission were being guided by when making determinations under the Veterans' Entitlement Act, could, on rare occasions, lead to confusion...

An issue lay in the fact that for a short period of time the templates had been constructed with an auto-populate setting on, which resulted in some instances, evidence weight being applied to information delegates received from medical advisors, when it may not have been the case...

To its credit, DVA has undertaken positive actions to correct the issue moving forward and the templates were corrected. However, no measures have been implemented to examine how this may have affected the few veterans who have received adverse determinations where the problematic template was used...

Although this is not a widespread failing, it nonetheless warrants an investigation to see what, if any, corrective measures might be implemented, so those affected might receive a reconsideration of their claim.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause an appropriate investigation, that will identify how veterans who have received an unfair decision might be identified, and how, if any, the unfair decision may be reconsidered.
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN5380)
Food Additives: Folate

Up to 40% of Australians have a MTHFR mutation. In this case folic acid is toxic to their system plus their body systems can't work to full potent due to lack of folate. Pregnant women are being told to take folic acid. This is increasing the rates of ADHD, Autism, Depression and Addiction etc for the children and adults who has the MTHFR mutation.

Common daily eating foods have regulation to have cheap synthetic folic acid added to it where if we could simply change that to actual folate instead, we could alleviate a lot of issues for kids and adults—affecting schools and prisons.
This is such a simple change that could have massive positive impact—there is a lot of science around this and is easily googleable.
We therefore ask the House to change food regulations to add actual folate, not the synthetic version of Folic Acid to foods in Australia. This could change the future of many families.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5381)
Disability Support Pension

The amount of disability support pension (DSP) you can receive is currently calculated based on your household income, including that of your spouse. Currently a couple is only able to earn a combined income of $360.00 a fortnight before the amount of DSP is reduced by $0.50 for each dollar over that amount. This is unliveable and disabled citizens are more likely to require financial assistance from family or friends. Provided rent in most locations is more than double $360 a fortnight change is required as a matter or urgency.

We therefore ask the House to either remove the inclusion of spousal income from the income and assets test or drastically increase the cap, to allow both parties of a couple to earn at least a liveable wage.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN5382)
Australian Constitution
We must stop the division of our people by radical governments.

In the heart of Australia, a united voice echoes the deep connection between its people and our land. Descendants of many, we stand as proud Australians with a vision of sovereignty rooted in equality.

We call for your pledge, your support, and your signature to realise this vision, we urge for constitutional reforms that empower all our citizens, granting them equal rights regardless of race, colour, or descent.

We envision an Australia where every individual holds power over their destinies and freedoms, enabling our children to flourish. Together, we shall lead this country into a brighter future as a united nation and united people under one flag.

Help us weave this vision into reality. Join us in building an Australia that stands as a beacon of equality and human dignity, honouring all our ancestors and shaping a legacy for generations to come.

We therefore ask the House to firmly advocate for the incorporation of a Bill of Rights into the Constitution. This bill would aim to enhance Australian democracy by enshrining the core rights of all Australians. These rights include freedom of choice, freedom of speech, protection of community values, safeguarding private property rights, and ensuring defence against the government favouring any religion, race, or foreign legal entities and individuals.
from 531 citizens (Petition No. EN5383)
COVID-19: Response

An urgent call is being made to establish a Royal Commission to thoroughly investigate the significant and lasting economic and social repercussions stemming from the abject failure of government policies during the pandemic. The widespread implementation of these measures has resulted in serious and lasting adverse impacts, demonstrating the failure of these strategies and necessitating a comprehensive assessment of the associated costs and an assurance that these same mistakes are never made again.

We therefore ask the House to establish a wide-ranging Royal Commission with terms of reference to properly investigate the Australian Federal and State Government pandemic response, including the following: the nature of Australia's soaring and continued excess mortality; the economic, social and public health impacts of school closures; the economic, social and public health effects of national and state border closures; the economic, social and public health effects of lockdowns; the economic, social and public health effects of vaccination mandates; the corporate capture of Australia's regulatory agencies, including, but not limited to the Therapeutic Goods Administration and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation; and, government censorship, propaganda, misinformation and disinformation during the pandemic.
from 52 citizens (Petition No. EN5385)
Banking and Financial Services

No Australian town, suburb or community should be left without reasonable local access to full banking services and physical notes and coins. Every Australian must be able to use cash to buy food and groceries if they choose.
We therefore ask the House to guarantee through legislation:
1) All Australians must be able to have reasonable local access to cash and full banking services.
2) All Australians must be able to choose to use cash as legal tender when paying for any and all goods and services at physical retailers.
from 116 citizens (Petition No. EN5391)
Human Rights: India

The surge in violence in Manipur, along with distressing reports of persecution against Christians and other minorities in India, highlights a critical concern for basic human rights. The escalating violence against Kuki-Christians in Manipur, India is deeply alarming, displaying distressing signs of genocide. The tragedy of innocent lives lost, property destruction, fear, and instability extend beyond the Kuki-christians, encompassing all minorities subjected to massacre and abuse under the present Indian government. These reports indicate potential breaches of United Nations human-rights, unfolding under the Hindutva agenda of the present Indian government.

Urgent condemnation, accountability, and sustained peace efforts are vital to combat these actions and nurture tolerance within diverse ethno-religious communities. Australia, rooted in democratic egalitarianism and devoted to human-rights, must denounce violence against Kuki-Christians. Religious freedom, devoid of fear is enshrined in international human rights agreements. As a nation that values diversity, democracy, and religious freedom, Australia has a responsibility to speak out against such violations.
We therefore ask the House to
-Unreservedly denounce the violence in Manipur; implore the Indian-government for rapid peace restoration and tackling underlying causes.
-Express grave apprehensions to Indian authorities concerning widespread Christian and minority persecution.
-Engage in diplomatic efforts to encourage a peaceful resolution to the conflicts and ensure the safety and well-being of all affected communities.
-Monitor the situation and collaborate with international organizations to ensure that human rights are upheld and protected in India.
Australia's moral duty lies in showcasing unwavering solidarity with persecuted Kuki-Christians, condemning the state-sponsored brutality they endure, and extending them support.
from 813 citizens (Petition No. EN5392)
Renewable Energy

This petition opposes the current proposal from the Commonwealth Minister for Climate Change and Energy to create a designated area in Australian Commonwealth waters in the Southern Ocean off the coast Port MacDonnell, South Australia for renewable energy projects, such as offshore wind.
This proposal will have a detrimental effect on industry, environment and community.

We therefore ask the House to reject any proposal to create a designated area or to allow wind turbines to be installed off the coast Port MacDonnell, South Australia for renewable energy projects, such as offshore wind.
from 4,649 citizens (Petition No. EN5394)
Multiculturalism: Pasifika

Pacific Islanders in Australia form less than 2% of Australia's population. From Tonga, to Samoa, to Cook Islands, to Niue, to Kiribati, to Tokelau, To Fiji, to Papua New Guinea, to Vanuatu and Solomon Islands, not to mention America Samoa, New Caledonia, Tuvalu, Hawaii and Marshall Islands. We also take into account West Papua and the Torres Strait islands who are also very much part of the Pacific Islands. The Pacific islands are represented in Australia with their rich culture and people as well. The creation of Pacific Island Culture hubs in communities identified to have large Pacific Island communities will help create a sense of community.
This petition promotes inclusion and connectedness, acknowledging shared history, Locally led and inclusive partnerships and Australian knowledge of the Pacific islands region.

We therefore ask the House to fund the creation of Pacific Island Cultural hubs in major states of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria where large Pacific Islander communities reside to provide a space to celebrate the Pacific Islanders Culture and provide access support services for Pasifika people in the local community.
from 34 citizens (Petition No. EN5395)
Workplace Relations
Women go through physical as well as emotional strain every month due to monthly menstrual cycle. This needs to be acknowledged and considered at all workplaces, on a national level.
It could be embarrassing for many women to be direct with their employer when it comes to asking for leave for menstrual discomfort and pain.
We need to understand and respect the natural physical challenges all women go through every month and to support them so that they can perform much better during their time of need.
Countries including Japan, Taiwan, Indonesia, South Korea, Spain, and Zambia currently offer their female residents paid menstrual leave.
We could be the next country acknowledging women in the workforce needs'.
We therefore ask the House to support the idea of introducing mandatory 10 days paid menstrual leave in addition to 10 days of sick leave, for all the working women in Australia.
from 131 citizens (Petition No. EN5396)
Veterans

Division 4 of the Veterans' Entitlement Act discriminates against Veterans who have disabilities under more than one Act from being granted the Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Payment because of what is known as the "alone" test. This Petition amends various provisions in the Act to remove the ambiguity pertaining to the 'alone test'.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Veterans Entitlement Act 1986—Division 4—Rates of Pensions Payable to Veterans by removing the word "alone" from the legislation and replacing it with "all accepted conditions".

This petition will bring justice and clarity to the legislation and eradicate the injustice caused by DVA Delegates when assessing Veterans claims under the VEA, in particular when using the "alone" test.
from 117 citizens (Petition No. EN5397)
Road Safety
Vehicle Event Data Recorders (EDRs), referred to as 'black boxes' are reliable technology for reporting near-crash, pre-crash, and crash data.

Access to EDR data provides practitioners with reliable data about approach speeds and other pre-impact behavior including seatbelt use, headlight operation, and braking performance. Obtaining robust crash event data (as opposed to relying on human observation or inference) is good scientific policy.
EDRs have been used in cars since 1970 and are widely in aviation/rail industries to monitor operator and vehicle behavior in critical events.

EDRs are not currently regulated in Australia. Australia is lagging other countries in its capability to collect accurate crash related data. EDRs have been regulated in the USA since 2006 and in Europe since 2022. EDRs are also mandated numerous other countries including China and Japan. Practitioners have urged the Australian Government to adopt a similar EDR-related regulation in line with the current National Road Safety Strategy 2021-2030.

The primary benefit of EDRs is their provision of immediate, accurate data. Rapid access to crash data saves time, money, and facilitates policy making. Research has shown that fleet vehicles equipped with EDRs resulted in a 20% reduction in crashes.

We therefore ask the House to consider as a matter of urgency regulating Event Data Recorders (EDRs) in vehicles. Without timely and accurate crash data, Australia will not be able to meet current road safety targets set out in the National Road Safety Strategy 2021-2030.
from 193 citizens (Petition No. EN5398)

subdebateinfo.title: Consulate-General of the Russian Federation: New South Wales

p.span: Consulate-General of the Russian Federation: New South Wales

Russia is a security threat to Australia. Its Consulate in Sydney serves no practical purpose that benefits the Australian-Russian relationship. Passports and other consular activities can be undertaken via the Russian embassy in Canberra with no loss of activities. Further, international sanctions mean that no trade activities will be conducted from the Sydney consulate. Notably, a recent poll shows 93% of Australians see Russia's foreign policy as a threat (Lowy Institute, 2023). And in the West, more than 600 Russian diplomats accused of spying were already expelled.

The Consulate's activities allegedly include coordinating espionage activities, gathering place for ultra-nationalists and harbouring Simeon Boikov, an Australian national with an arrest warrant. Mr Boikov has utilised the Consulate for cyber and physical attacks on Australian people and organisations; runs live streams that promote anti-Australian Russian propaganda; he calls to deploy nuclear weapons retaliation and sends money to Africa to finance destabilisation in the region.

Furthermore, Russia continues to breach international law and perpetrate war crimes against Ukrainians, with the UN reporting that women have been gang-raped, men castrated, children sexually abused (18/10/22) and stating that Russia performs deliberate state-endorsed torture (15/6/23).

We therefore ask the House to seek the closure of the Russian Consulate in Sydney and the expulsion of its staff from Australia to reduce the threat of espionage, reflect the national interest and show Government's strong opposition to the war. The Consulate staff, especially Simeon Boikov, have breached their diplomatic duties and no longer warrant immunity.
from 1,405 citizens (Petition No. EN5399)
Renewable Energy

This petition is opposing the Climate Change and Energy Minister Chris Bowen's plans to build an offshore windfarm off the coast of the Illawarra. Chris Bowens plans leave affected citizens to negotiate with private individual companies who will hold licences to develop these structures in terms of scope, and impacts. There is no proposed limits in height, distance from shore or number of turbines that can be installed. There is also no clear plan for remediation or disposal once turbines reach their end of life. They will be visible from shore. This will not only be damaging to tourism but will also impact fishing, shipping and marine life.
We therefore ask the House to
scrap the Illawarra as a proposed site if the majority of submission and community reject the proposal.
from 69 citizens (Petition No. EN5402)
Workers Compensation Insurance
Businesses who do residential cleaning for a living are being categorised under the BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY by the worker compensation schemes (like WorkCover).

This is perhaps one of the leading causes of regular family run cleaning businesses going under. Competing companies are forcing workers to work under their own ABN where they often avoid paying Super, Insurance, award rates, penalties and more. The practice of forcing businesses into the building industry classification for insurance may be a major reason for businesses doing the wrong thing. It is very veasible to think that there would be much less worker abuse in the country if things were different.
This practice of lumping all cleaning companies under the BUILDING CLEANING category must stop and new categories should be made for cleaning residential homes.

Below is the insurance cost for a business in $ per $100 of wages for many industries. It is genuinely shocking to see no category for regular cleaning and even more shocking that people getting paid less than 25% of those in the building cleaning category should be paying the same insurance premiums.
We therefore ask the House to consult the Workers' compensation regulator who creates the ANZSIC categories for state bodies (like WorkCover QLD) to operate their premiums by.
Ask just exactly WHY a category for one of the most common small businesses in the country does not exist. Residential cleaning.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN5403)
Animal Welfare

The illegal shooting of wildlife is a crisis in our nation, with tens of thousands killed every year. This practice devastates wildlife populations, disrupts ecosystems and shatters the well-being of many in our communities. Current legislation, including the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, fails to deter or punish perpetrators.

Every night, people are subjected to the harrowing sounds of gunshots, the haunting sight of wounded or killed animals (including young) and the aggressive invasion of spotlighters shining lights into homes, along public roads and across private property. The persistent violence not only inflicts unbearable suffering on our wildlife but leaves many people feeling vulnerable and abandoned. In our cities similar crimes would prompt a rapid police response. Such is the injustice!
The fight against this violence is made impossible by a prevailing sentiment that roos are a pest! Those who are traumatized feel abandoned and trapped in a culture that tolerates cruelty!
We therefore ask the House to establish a National Wildlife Patrol Service, dedicated to preventing the illegal shooting of wildlife, with the power to:
*Conduct regular and targeted patrols in rural and remote areas, utilizing modern technology to identify and prosecute offenders.
*Rigorously enforce existing laws such as the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.
By establishing this service, you can protect tens of thousands of native animals, help our ecosystems and heal the traumas inflicted on our fellow Australians.
from 206 citizens (Petition No. EN5408)
Australian Constitution
The Referendum to establish a Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice includes

"the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice may make representations to the Parliament and the Executive Government of the Commonwealth on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples".
Whereas Parliament is easily understood by citizens, Executive Government may be much less so.

We therefore ask the House to consider supporting a program to educate the public on the structure and function of Executive Government. A well-funded campaign of advertisements in all avenues of public media could achieve that aim, in order to benefit the progress of the Referendum.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5409)
Parliamentary Standards: Lobbyists

According to the SMH (3 May 2023) there are 891 Lobbyists with open access to certain areas of Parliament House and Members. Sponsored passes for anyone, who is not an employee or contracted supplier to our Government should have these passes revoked immediately.

Guest passes ONLY should be issued to past Politicians, Lobbyists and family members. I fear the open access allows for potential unwanted influence to Parliament Representatives to the potential detriment of the electorate they represent.
Guest passes should require a purpose for the visit confirmed/ approved by the sponsor.
It would appear Lobbyists have a potential "back-door voice" that I vote NO to.
We therefore ask the House to limit open access passes to Parliament House to Government Employees, Contractors and Elected members only.
Sponsored passes to be removed and be replaced with Daily Guest passes.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5411)
COVID-19: Response

Lately there has been increased media coverage of new Covid variants and rising case numbers. "Experts" have been advising people to wear masks and get booster shots. It seems as though we are being primed for the reintroduction of Covid restrictions. My experience from 2020 taught me that one must be pre-emptive rather than reactive. While many of the Covid measures were implemented at the state level, the Federal Government exerted a great deal of influence over the states' responses to Covid. They subsidised lockdowns through schemes such as JobKeeper. They purchased vaccines and made the registration of Covid vaccinations mandatory, which enabled the states to impose vax passes. They engaged in censorship on social media, quashing the voices of those who spoke out against the measures the states were taking. They imposed hotel quarantine and built quarantine camps. They prevented people from entering and leaving the country. They provided ADF personnel to enforce state lockdowns. They discussed policy with state leaders in National Cabinet meetings. And so on. The states could not have imposed such harsh lockdowns for so long without support from the Federal Government. There were also Federal mask and vaccination requirements. Any return to lockdowns, mask mandates, vaccine mandates, curfews, border closures, travel bans, hotel quarantine, quarantine camps, social distancing, etc., would be totally unacceptable.
We therefore ask the House to oppose the introduction of any new Federal Covid restrictions and oppose the facilitation, coordination or subsidisation of any new state restrictions.
from 66 citizens (Petition No. EN5416)
Skilled Migration Program

I represent group of residents of Australia who are living in regional Australia and have committed to this country for a significant amount of time in regional jobs. Some of us have been waiting for our visa approvals onshore more than 12 months to 24months. The bridging visas cannot give us access to medicare, Govt subsidised tuition fees, permanent jobs (companies do not prefer to hire us due to nature of our bridging visa status), cannot make significant investments in regionals areas for our future and cannot demand competent salaries. The wait times have added to the 191 visa timelines as well 2+3+1, totalling 6years to get our PR on 191.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Expedite bridging visas grants onshore for 491/494, including s56 request
2. Some applicants have got their grants in just 4-6months in non-priority occupations onshore, neglecting the backlog waiting since years 2021, 2022

3. Include the wait times of bridging visa as part of 3year commitment for PR visa 191 so we have fair access to apply for PR visa—onshore applicants. We are also committed to state obligations which States bind us to remain in their territory. All this commitment should have fair access to 191 visa fulfilling conditions.
from 510 citizens (Petition No. EN5417)
Australian Constitution

The current proposed referendum question combines two decisions: altering the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia and altering the Constitution to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. This petition is to request these questions are separated so voters can freely exercise their right to express their opinion on both decisions and ensure the accuracy of the result. Separating the questions will minimise confusion for voters who might otherwise not be able to choose an appropriate option to reflect their views. Given the emotional and financial investment of all Australians in this process, it is essential the design of the question does not lead to a result that is unsatisfactory for the majority.
We therefore ask the House to introduce and pass legislation to separate the referendum question into two questions:
1. to alter the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia
2. to alter the Constitution to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice.
We call for this to ensure that voters can consider each decision separately based on the information available to them, providing clear results that accurately reflect the opinions of voters.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN5419)
Australian Electoral Commission
Many voters think the aec rules are confusing and can be manipulated for a biased result
We therefore ask the House to enforce this rule with the aec to make voting more transparent and equal
Also it would make the system more accountable and outcomes clearer
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN5421)
Australian Competition and Consumer Commission

The ACCC has been as negligent as ASIC when it comes to responding to reports of alleged misconduct. Consumers, especially those who purchase high value goods such as motor vehicles (MVs) and recreational vehicles (RVs), are consistently being caused serious financial, physical, emotional and mental health harm, simply because they purchase 'lemon' defective products from a supplier who refuses to comply with the Australian Consumer Law (ACL).

To date, the ACCC has only prosecuted one RV business ever (Jayco Corporation Pty Ltd), and that was an abject failure of mismanagement. Even after multiple prosecutions of MV businesses and court enforceable undertakings, MV businesses continue to breach the ACL.

Both industries regularly force consumers to engage in expensive and protracted litigation where the defects in the goods are obviously manufacturing defects. The losses can be in the tens to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Many are vulnerable consumers and have their lives and retirements destroyed. The ACCC has known about the problems with multiple suppliers in both industries and do little to nothing to prevent this conduct, where they do have actions available to them in the ACL but choose not to use them.

We therefore ask the House to add the ACCC to the 'Inquiry into ASIC's capacity and capability to respond to reports of alleged misconduct', as the terms of reference are relevant to both Federal regulatory bodies and the problems in the market place are also common to both.
from 477 citizens (Petition No. EN5423)
Australian Constitution

The First Fleet brought more than just convicts to our shores. It is well overdue that we acknowledge and pay respect to the thousands of first settlers, free and convicts that built Australia to what it is today. This small group of hard-working, mostly men and boys are forgotten in our history which is very much geared to one segment of our population. Australia was built on hard yakka, blood sweat and tears, so do the right thing Australia and sign a petition to have these people, our founding fathers acknowledged in our Constitution and Parliament. Act up Australia, and show some respect so that the World knows we can move beyond the current discriminatory, racist and disgusting overlooking of these hard-working people.

We therefore ask the House to formally acknowledge the contribution that free settlers, both convicts and free have made to the development of Australia. In addition draft an amendment to the Australian Constitution to reflect this.
from 17 citizens (Petition No. EN5427)
Climate Change

Climate change is an urgent global crisis that demands immediate action. Empowering individual consumers to make informed choices is crucial. Australians lack accessible information regarding the carbon footprint of the products they purchase. This limitation inhibits their ability to make environmentally responsible choices and places the onus solely on producers to act sustainably.

Furthermore, by making the carbon footprint of imported products visible, consumers may be more inclined to choose goods made locally, many of which will likely be made with reduced transportation emissions. This would act as an incentive for consumers to support local manufacturers and producers. This could rejuvenate local economies, create jobs, and set a precedence for sustainable business practices within Australia.

We therefore ask the House to Representatives to enact legislation requiring that all retail goods imported into Australia from 2027 onwards be labelled with their CO2 equivalent emissions. Such labelling should be standardized, easily visible, and should include the total emissions generated from raw material extraction to manufacturing, shipping, and disposal. This initiative will bring about greater transparency, empowering consumers to make more informed decisions and driving companies towards sustainability. It is a small but essential step that allows everyone to participate in mitigating the devastating impacts of climate change actively.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5428)
Australian Constitution
Self ID laws in Queensland take away the right to freely express and communicate a difference of opinion or point of view through words, language, the written word and vocabulary to the legislation .

We therefore ask the House to add Freedom of Speech to the Australian Constitution to allow Australians to freely express opinions and points of view through all types of speech, spoken ,signed , written or otherwise under law
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN5429)
Termination of Pregnancy

In Australia women have the option to opt out of motherhood however men cannot opt out of fatherhood. We ask that equality is insured to all Australian citizens. We need to ensure that all citizens are treated fairly and equally without bias towards gender. We recognise there could a myriad of reasons as to why a woman would seek an abortion. We believe it is only fair to extend those same rights to Australian men. A financial or legal abortion would ensure that no Australian man is forced into fatherhood and could opt out. Just as we must respect a woman's bodily autonomy forcing men into unwanted fatherhood forces them into transactional relationships they do not want.
We therefore ask the House to ensure equality for all Australian men and allow men to enact a financial abortion.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5430)

subdebateinfo.title: Child Safety: Bullying, Harassment and Violence

p.span: Child Safety: Bullying, Harassment and Violence

In 2009 a national study showed that approximately one in four (27%) Australian students in Years 4—9 report being bullied frequently (defined as every few weeks or more often). Frequent school bullying was also highest among Year 5 (32%) and Year 8 (29%) students. Peers are present as onlookers in 85% of bullying interactions and play a central role in the bullying process.
We therefore ask the House to :
1. recognises the tragedy of bullying, and recognise that bullying can lead to depression and suicides
2. call on the Minister for Education to support reforms to the education system to educate, better recognise bullying, and enact efficient reporting processes.
3. call on the Attorney General to explore methods through law reform to deter bullying for older school children.

4. call on the Minister for Health or Minister for Mental Health to work with the Minister for Education to support counselling services and other related services to be provided more efficiently, and to ensure those services are more accessible.
5. work with state and territorial governments to support the efforts to mitigate the effects of bullying.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN5433)
Pornography

We, as citizens of Australia, rise united against an alarming and escalating crisis that imperils the very fabric of our society. The pervasive scourge of explicit po*nography and sexual content is not only tearing at our moral foundations but also fostering a breeding ground for heinous crimes that threaten our safety, dignity, and future. These materials have a detrimental impact on individuals, families, relationships, and societal values. They contribute to the objectification of individuals, perpetuate harmful stereotypes, and can lead to harmful behaviours and attitudes and crimes. Children and young people are particularly vulnerable to the negative effects of exposure to explicit content, as it can shape their perceptions of healthy relationships and sexual behaviours.

This crisis transcends mere content; it is a crisis of values, relationships, and human dignity. Explicit material infiltrates our homes, schools, and workplaces, systematically warping our perception of consent, respect, and love. It sows seeds of objectification that sprout into attitudes of entitlement and disrespect.

The dangers stretch beyond distorted beliefs. We must confront the alarming rise in crimes that are fuelled by explicit content—crimes such as harassment, cyberbullying, and even human and sex trafficking. These insidious activities thrive in the shadows of a society that tolerates the degradation of human beings.

We therefore ask the House to Enact an immediate and unequivocal ban on explicit content. Safeguard our society, protect our youth, and eliminate the breeding ground for associated crimes. Implement stringent regulations, fund comprehensive and non-explicit sexual education and bolster mental health support.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN5435)
Live Animal Exports

The evidence is clear—despite various regulations, rules and industry proclaimed 'improvements' to the live animal export the trade, the live export of sheep by sea will always result in the suffering of Australian sheep.
And whilst this is obvious to so many, the live export industry is still calling on the government to overturn its commitment to phase out the trade.

It is utterly unacceptable on every level to expose animals to this kind of cruelty. They are live sentient beings, and the practice of this trade hardly needs any explanation. You need only look at the video prepared by Lynn White from Animals Australia who travelled with the ABC journalists to the middle east and filmed the entire disgraceful journey and despicable delivery practice at the destination. Anyone with any conscience or moral platform will be disgusted.
Help end this trade now.
Australia the country I was born and grew up in, surely can not now be a country that supports and condones unspeakable cruelty.
Stand up, step up, and let's finally end this despicable trade.
We therefore ask the House to finally put an end to Live Export, let Australia stand for the rights of all living beings and for Australia to have zero tolerance for cruelty on all levels.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN5439)
Housing
The Housing/Rental Crisis in Australia is Woefully out of hand, and only getting worse with Inflation on the rise and cost of living increasing, whilst workers wages don't nearly keep up.
We therefore ask the House to request a royal commission into the housing/rental crisis. It's root causes, and potential ways to remedy/fix the issue.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN5440)
Housing
Rental standards aren't monitored by upstanding staff or clear standards for living conditions, leaving many renters in subpar conditions and little or slow action (if any) on issues that are raised.
This is at the mercy of landlords' decisions, not a government regulation—which can be affected by their budget, or unnecessary.
When comparing government websites from other countries (e.g. NZ), with clear minimum standards of living that need to be legally upheld, Australia is lacking.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a government-regulated organisation (not dissimilar to police or the ATO) of experts, that is able to regularly maintain, enforce, and investigate clear minimal standards of living—of which can then be added to (not subtracted from), depending on the state governments.
Some examples of actions that can be taken with this organisation may be (but are not limited to):
- Clear standards of living and many examples in different languages
- Simple reporting of unjust behaviour with responses of investigations/audits and fines
- A registry of real estate agencies and landlords
- Auditors who regularly inspect properties to a minimal standard
- Real estate agent licensing to ensure agents are up to date with laws and standards
- Advice and hotline numbers, and government officials (multi-lingual) stationed for advice
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN5441)
Renewable Energy

Off shore wind turbines have a negative impact on whale migration and bird life and they are an economic failure with high construction and maintenance costs as seen in the USA and Europe. Siemens Gamesa ended the year with a quarterly loss of E 884 million ($ AUD 1.4 billion), more than double the prior year, and net debt of E 1.9 billion. Spain's latest manufacturer. Vestas has added E 210 million in warranty provisions for repairs in the December quarter a Danish company.( source Rachel Williamson Renew Economy article 9 February 2023.) The hype about offshore wind energy keeps getting scuttled by reality. That's the clear conclusion from last month's announcement that Spanish utility company Avangrid was halting work on the proposed 1,200 megawatt Commonwealth Wind project because it was "no longer viable" ( Forbes Robert Bryce 18 November 2022 ) North Atlantic ocean. See "Thrown to the wind" a documentary about how offshore wind turbines are killing Right whales with 1,000 of wind turbines making noise pollution ! How can Federal Energy Minister Mr Chris Bowen allows these off shore wind turbines developments to happen in the Illawarra and Greater Newcasltle regions when in possession of this knowledge from emails and messages sent to him? These projects planned are neither renewable or sustainable if sanctioned to proceed? Would the Minister be derelict in his duties to taxpayers and the public purse if he did not immediately cancel these developments?
We therefore ask the House to vote No
from 788 citizens (Petition No. EN5442)
Live Animal Exports
ANIMAL CRUELTY
We therefore ask the House to BAN LIVE ANIMAL EXPORTS NOW, OR ASAP!!
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN5443)
Capital Punishment

Legalizing the death penalty for convicted pedophiles serves as a powerful deterrent and sends a clear message that we will not tolerate such abhorrent behavior. It would act as a deterrent for potential offenders, knowing that their actions could cost them their lives. The fear of capital punishment could potentially prevent countless innocent children from becoming victims.

Furthermore, the death penalty serves as a form of retribution for the victims and their families. It provides a sense of closure and justice, knowing that the perpetrator will face the ultimate consequences for their actions. It is a way for society to demonstrate its commitment to protecting children and to standing up against those who seek to harm them.

While we understand that there are concerns regarding the potential for wrongful convictions, we believe that with stringent safeguards and thorough investigation processes, the risk can be minimized. Implementing strict guidelines, such as DNA evidence requirements and multiple levels of review, can help ensure that only the most heinous and unquestionable cases are subject to the death penalty.
We therefore ask the House to debate on the legalisation of the death penalty for convicted peohpiles
from 42 citizens (Petition No. EN5445)
Disability Services: Child Care

In Australia, children with profound disabilities and medical complexity are being systemically excluded from mainstream childcare models. Current legislative constraints force childcare providers to discriminate against such children. This is morally wrong.

Under the NDIS, these children's families are forced to pay up to 11 times the cost for care supports than typical families who can access subsidised childcare. This discrepancy puts enormous pressure on their already vulnerable situations.

All children have a fundamental human right to freedom from discrimination. This requires that they have equal access to meaningful early childhood educational opportunities regardless of their medical situation or disability status.
Complex children deserve and need a new childcare subsidy that meets their specific requirements.
Your signature can help ensure this happens.
We therefore ask the House to
• Legislate that all early childhood education and care providers be included in the Disability Standards for Education of 2005.

• Amend the Family Assistance Law (the basis for Commonwealth child care fee assistance) to include a new subsidy for vulnerable families of children with profound disabilities and medical complexities, and put appropriate policies in place to guide the application and other requirements of the subsidy.

• Fund research (including feasibility studies) into the social and economic benefits of a new early childhood education and care model (including the provision of appropriate facilities and services) that properly meets the needs of this demographic.
from 212 citizens (Petition No. EN5446)
Migration

A cohort of non-citizens in Australia have been living in Australia on bridging visas A, B, C, and E for more than the last 10 years with children born here. These young kids become Australian citizens under citizenship law on their 10th birthday.
These parents have no visa option allowing them to live here. Leaving Australia because the parents do not hold a visa damages the future lives of Australian citizen children.
Difficulties of current visa options:
• Skilled Visa(491/190/189)-Extremely competitive, BVE holders are ineligible to lodge these visas, stay offshore until visa decision.
• Contributory Parent Visas (subclass 143/173)- Need a sponsor; must be lodged offshore due to parents' visa status, Processing time-12 years, Fee—nearly $50000/parent
• Employer Sponsored (186/482/494)—S48 bar, stay offshore until visa decision.

We therefore ask the House to provide a pathway allowing these parents to stay permanently in Australia. The parents require a favourable substantive visa which allows them to lodge future visas onshore for PR based on their eligibility.
The UK Government has formulated an immigration policy for the parents of such children to be granted a favourable visa.
As Government is supporting the refugees, the parents of Australian citizen children should be looked after too.

A substantive visa or permanent visa pathway provides stability to these families, enabling them to raise their children with peace of mind. These children are the future of Australia, and we must empower them to achieve their goals to support a robust economy. Our country does not wish for a miserable youth.
from 11,147 citizens (Petition No. EN5447)
Working Holiday Maker Program

We, the undersigned, are writing to express our concern and request a change in the current regulations regarding the 88 days requirement for visa holders seeking to extend their stay in Australia. We believe that the days spent volunteering inside a charity sector should be recognized and counted towards fulfilling this requirement.

Many travelers come to Australia with Working Holiday Visas or other temporary visas that allow them to work, study, volunteer and explore the country. To extend their stay, these visa holders are required to complete 88 days of specified work in regional areas. However, the current system does not fully account for the valuable contributions of those giving there time inside different charities.We, the petitioners, therefore request that the relevant authorities consider and implement changes to the regulations so that days spent volunteering inside any charity are counted towards the 88 days requirement.

We therefore ask the House to include volunteering work has a vital component of Australia's well being. Individuals volunteering for charities play a crucial role in the community Their hard work should be acknowledged and rewarded. volunteering work can be physically demanding, often requiring time out of work hours. It may involve working with citizens and help the people and animals in need during the full calendar year. By including days spent in charities as part of the 88 days requirement, more individuals will be encouraged to participate in the life of the community, which will ultimately benefit the sector and address volunteers shortages.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5448)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 31 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence dated 7 November 2022 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning petition reference EN4105. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your email has been forwarded to me for reply.

The Albanese Government understands access to safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians. The Government is committed to an ambitious housing agenda which will boost the supply of all housing to address the cost of housing whether you are buying or renting.

The National Rental Affordability Scheme (NRAS, the Scheme) is an Australian Government affordable housing initiative, delivered in partnership with state and territory governments which was terminated by the former Federal Liberal Government in 2014. There are dwellings remaining in the Scheme which will continue to offer reduced rents until 2026. It was announced in the 2014-15 Budget, there will be no further funding rounds or new allocations of NRAS incentives beyond those currently allocated in the Scheme and held by approved participants.

At the conclusion of the Scheme, NRAS dwellings will remain subject to all relevant state and territory government tenancy laws, with respect to lease agreements and rental increases. Some NRAS allocations are held by endorsed charities, which includes Community Housing Providers (CHPs). Some CHPs may continue to offer reduced rents.

In regards to the request of the petition in relation to tenancy rights, while the regulation of residential tenancies, agreements and rental pricing, is a matter for state and territory governments, the Albanese Labor Government continues to work with all tiers of government to deliver better housing outcomes.

At National Cabinet in August this year the Commonwealth, state and territory governments committed to A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia. This included developing a nationally consistent framework including a requirement for genuine reasonable grounds for eviction, moving towards limiting rental increases to once a year and phasing in minimum rental standards.
These changes will make a tangible impact for the almost one-third of Australian households who rent.
