The Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.

These housing challenges didn't happen overnight and cannot be solved by one government alone. As mentioned, the Albanese Government is working with the states and territories and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
These measures are in addition to the work we've already started.

The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund to support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years has, for the second time, been introduced into the Parliament. We've reintroduced this important legislation because we want to use every process available to ensure tens of thousands of new homes are built for Australians.
The Albanese Government will deliver the Help to Buy scheme with state and territory governments to help thousands of Australians into home ownership.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility, has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in social and affordable rental homes, with projects already under construction as a result of this funding.

The National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation's liability cap has been increased by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator.
We've delivered the largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rate.
Tax incentives have been provided to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market.

Federal funding of $1.7 billion has been provided for a one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement with States and Territories, including a $67.5 million boost to homelessness funding over the next year.

More than 50,000 Australians have been helped into home ownership through the Home Guarantee Scheme, including more than 6,000 through the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee. The scheme has now been expanded significantly—changes will see friends, siblings, and other family members eligible for joint applications under the First Home Guarantee and the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee.

We've also established an interim National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, while legislation goes through the Parliament to create the Council as an independent body.

In addition, the Albanese Government is developing a National Housing and Homelessness Plan (the Plan) to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

The Plan will be informed by advice provided by the newly established National Housing Supply and Affordability Council and will set out the reforms needed to improve housing and homelessness outcomes across the spectrum, including to make it easier for Australians to buy a home, easier to rent, and reduce homelessness.

The public submission stage of the Plan is now open. If you would like to find out more about consultation activities or encourage involvement from your constituents, you can visit the website at https://engage.dss.gov.au.

Members of the public are now able to participate in submission and consultation activities to share their housing experiences to help inform the Plan. Local governments, not-for- profit and civil society organisations, industry bodies, superannuation funds and other experts in housing, finance and urban development will also take part in consultation activities.

As you can see, the Albanese Government's ambitious housing reform agenda is designed to boost supply, increase housing affordability and make positive and practical differences for make positive and practical differences for Australians seeking housing.
We are doing this to make sure more Australians have an affordable place to call home.
The Albanese Government has added to its broad housing agenda at every opportunity.
It's a plan we are proud of and after a decade of little action we are working hard to turn around the housing challenges in Australia today.
I appreciate you for bringing this matter to my attention. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Ukraine
Dear Chair

Thank you for raising petition EN4122 presented to the House of Representatives regarding military assistance to Ukraine. I appreciate you raising your concerns on this matter and understand there was a technical issue which delayed it being forwarded to me.

The Government has repeatedly condemned Russia's unprovoked and illegal invasion of Ukraine, and continues to call for its withdrawal from Ukrainian territory. The Government is providing military assistance to Ukraine to support its defence.

Since the petition, Australia has gifted more Bushmasters to Ukraine. On 12 July 2023 the Prime Minister announced another 30 Bushmasters to Ukraine, bringing the total number of gifted Bushmasters to 120.

Australia has also provided Ukraine with 105mm artillery ammunition and 70 military vehicles. Australia will also deploy an E-7A Wedgetail aircraft to help protect a vital gateway of assistance to Ukraine. These packages bring the total value of Australia's military assistance to Ukraine to $710 million. The Government continues to consider options for further support to Ukraine.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 7 November 2022, received by my Office on 25 July 2023, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral EN4130, on financial independence, suspension from Centrelink, and homelessness services.

Australia's social security system is a non-contributory system designed to support the basic living standards of all Australians. It is a means-tested, residence-based system, designed to provide income support to people who, for reasons such as age, unemployment or ill health, are unable to support themselves.

A range of social security payments are available for people who are looking for work or temporarily unable to work. For example, JobSeeker Payment is an income support payment that provides financial assistance to people aged 22 years to age-pension age, who have capacity to work now or in the near future.

Eligibility for JobSeeker Payment requires that a person is unemployed for the purposes of JobSeeker Payment, has income and assets below relevant thresholds and, unless temporarily exempted, meets mutual obligation requirements. These requirements include actively looking for a job, and undertaking activities to improve their work prospects, such as further study, training, approved voluntary work or Work for the Dole.

Under current arrangements, job seekers may be subject to demerits or payment suspensions if they do not meet mutual obligation requirements, without a valid reason. Job seekers may qualify for an exemption from their mutual obligation requirements when their personal circumstances make it difficult for them to meet those requirements. A person may qualify for an exemption for a range of reasons including, but not limited to, having a medical condition, experiencing homelessness or experiencing family and domestic violence.

If a recipient receives a demerit which they do not agree with they can contact their employment services provider or the Digital Services Contact Centre if they are with Workforce Australia Online. Where a person disagrees with a Services Australia decision, such as a decision to stop payment, they have the right under social security law to request a review of that decision.

In relation to grant arrangements for homelessness service providers—the Commonwealth Grants Rules and Guidelines 2017 (CGRGs) establish the Commonwealth grants policy framework. The CGRGs contain the key legislative and policy requirements, and explain the better practice principles of grants administration.

Commonwealth officials plan and define the details of a grant program, including how it will be implemented to achieve intended outcomes. A range of issues are considered in developing a grant opportunity, including but not limited to:
establishing the rationale for the grant opportunity, in particular what outcomes are required and how these will be measured;
defining the operational objectives;
the eligibility and assessment criteria;
how grant applications are considered and selected;
how grantees are notified and receive grant payments;
how grantees will be monitored and evaluated.
Specific requirements for each program, such as the need for ongoing support for people experiencing homelessness, is considered during the grant program design phase.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services. Ms Rishworth
Illicit Drugs: Cannabis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 July 2023 regarding Petition EN4168, which called for the legalisation of the recreational use and cultivation of cannabis for adults in Australia.

The Government does not propose to legalise the production, sale and use of cannabis for recreational purposes. Legislation relating to the legalisation or decriminalisation of illicit drugs, including cannabis, are largely matters for state and tenitory governments.

The Government is committed to preventing and minimising the harms associated with the use of illicit drugs on individuals, families and communities across Australia. The approach is set out in the National Drug Strategy 2017-2026. The Strategy outlines a balanced approach between health and law enforcement, and provides a national commitment to harm minimisation through evidence-based demand, supply and ha1m reduction initiatives.

The use of cannabis for recreational purposes has been linked to a number of short and long-term adverse effects. Twenty per cent of Australia's drug and alcohol treatment services are being provided to people identifying cannabis as their principal drug of concern. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), which is often at high levels in illicit cannabis products, can exacerbate mental health conditions as well as other health conditions. Further information on cannabis harms can be accessed at: https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/marijuana.

While recreational use of cannabis remains illegal, the Government supp01is the needs of patients to access a safe, legal and reliable supply of medicinal cannabis products for the management of painful and chronic conditions. Information on Australia's medicinal cannabis licensing scheme can be found at: https://www.tga.gov.au/accessing-medicinal-cannabis-patient.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Personal Information and Privacy
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition EN4201 to pass legislation banning the outing of LGBTQIA+ youth. Unfortunately, due to a technical error, your correspondence was not received by my office until 26 July 2023. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government believes that all Australians are entitled to respect, safety, and the opportunity to participate in society, regardless of their sexual orientation, gender identity, or intersex status.
LGBTQIA+ youth are entitled to protection under Australian anti-discrimination law.

The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (Cth) prohibits discrimination on these grounds in a range of areas of public life, including employment, education and in the provision of goods, services and facilities. The Fair Work Act 2009 also contains an anti-discrimination framework applicable to most Australian workplaces. This framework prohibits workplace discrimination that is based on sexual orientation, gender identity or intersex status (among other protected attributes).

Within schools, the Government has implemented a range of programs to support LGBTQIA+ youth. The Foundation to Year 10 (F-10) Australian Curriculum includes the general capabilities of Personal and Social Capability and Ethical Understanding, which encourage students to engage respectfully with LGBTQIA+ issues. The Student Wellbeing Hub, which provides free information and resources for educators, students and parents, includes specific resources designed to support LGBTQIA+ students and their families, and to assist educators to promote an inclusive classroom environment. The Hub can be accessed at www.studentwellbeinghub.edu.au.

While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, state and territory governments and non-government education authorities and individual schools are responsible for the day-to-day delivery of education and management of schools, including the development of policies relating to student information.

The Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) is currently conducting a review of religious exemptions for educational institutions in Government anti-discrimination law. The Government views the ALRC review as a first step towards implementing the Government's commitment to extending anti-discrimination protections to more Australians, including to students and staff in religious schools. The review's formal submission process closed on 24 February 2023. Stakeholder feedback received during this process is being thoroughly considered by the ALRC and will be used to inform its final advice, to be provided to the Government by 31 December 2023. Further information is available at www.alrc.gov.au/inguiry/anti-discrimination-laws.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Youth, Dr Aly
Media
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4258. This petition requests the House of Representatives consider implementing legislation to address the concentration of media ownership across newspapers, radio and television.
I apologise for the delay in responding. As a result of a technical e1rnr I received your petition refe1nl on 25 July 2023.

The signatories of this petition express concern that concentration of media ownership across newspapers, radio and television is resulting in a decrease in the quality and accuracy of news. To address this, the petition requests that the House of Representatives consider legislation to:
Limit foreign ownership of Australian media assets to 15% and ban access to any board seats.
Reintroduce cross media ownership restrictions limiting ownership to only one of the three traditional mediums.
Limit national population reach for any individual asset to 75% for TV & radio and limit state and territo1y reach to 40% for newspapers within each individual state and territ01y.
Require the industry as a whole to contribute to annual funding of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).

The Australian Government supports a diverse and sustainable media sector. We recognise that quality news and public interest journalism play an important role the functioning of Australian society and democracy. Australian media organisations play a crucial role in informing Australians about events and developments that are important to their daily lives and enable them to participate in our democratic processes. Journalism is vital in holding those in positions of power to account and exposing wrong doing and injustice.

The Government is focused on implementing practical measures that support the long-term viability of the sector. These include a $29 million local news and community broadcasting transition package to suppo1t regional, local and community media. They also include steps to modernise current policy settings to keep pace with ongoing changes to the media landscape.

On 14 November 2022, I announced the first step towards a news measurement framework for the digital era: that the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) would consult on a news measurement framework for diversity and localism in Australia. The ACMA unde1took public consultation between January and March 2023. It is considering the feedback and will provide further information on the finalisation and implementation of the news measurement framework later in 2023. Further information can be found at: acma.gov.au/consultations/2023-01/new-framework-measuring-media-diversity-australia.

The Government has also committed to developing a News Media Assistance Program to secure the evidence base needed to inform longer term news media policy interventions and to develop measures to support public interest journalism and media diversity. We will continue to monitor the status of media concentration in Australia as we develop this evidence base.

The national broadcasters—ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS)—are ousted institutions that strengthen Australia's media diversity, contribute to the cultural and social fabric of the nation.

In recognition of their important role, the Government moved the ABC and the SBS to 5-year funding terms commencing 1 July 2023 as part of the 2023-24 Budget. These new arrangements extend previous multi-year funding arrangements.

Over the 5-year term to 30 June 2028, the ABC will receive $6.0 billion, and the SBS will receive $1.8 billion. The transition to 5-year funding terms will provide the national broadcasters with more funding stability, allowing them to plan with more confidence. The ABC also received $32.0 million over 4 years from 2022-23 to expand transmission, content production, and capacity-building in the Inda-Pacific region.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Gambling
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 7 November 2022 on behalf of 20 signatories regarding Petition EN4274—Have online poker unbanned in Australia. I note that due to a technical error, your email was received in my office on 26 July 2023. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government recognises the ongoing community concerns about the harms associated with online gambling. The Government is committed to guaranteeing online gambling takes place under a robust legislative framework with strong consumer protections. The current priority of the Government for online gambling is harm minimisation and to deliver consumer protection measures that are aligned with community expectations.

On 15 September 2022, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs launched an inquiry into online gambling and its impacts on those experiencing gambling harm. The Committee examined a range of issues, including the effectiveness of current gambling advertising restrictions, and regulatory and licensing regimes around online gambling.

The Committee handed down its final report on 28 June 2023 and the Government is now considering the Committee's 31 recommendations. Information about the inquiry and its final report can be found at:
.www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/House/Social_Policy_and_Legal Affairs/Onlinegamblingimpacts.
Separately, the Government is progressing a number of important consumer protections to reduce online gambling harms, including:

National Self-Exclusion Register (BetStop): On 21 August 2023, the Government launched BetStop—the National Self-Exclusion Register, which allows individuals experiencing gambling harms to exclude themselves from Australian licensed online wagering services for three months, up to a lifetime. The Government will shortly introduce mandatory customer pre-verification requirements to open a betting account. Pre-verification will ensure protection for underage or self-excluded customers from accessing online gambling services.

Banning credit betting: on 28 April 2023, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, the Minister for Social Services and I, announced the Government will legislate a ban on the use of credit cards for online wagering. The Government expects to introduce legislation by the end of 2023.

Consistent gambling messaging: new evidence-based gambling taglines were introduced on 30 March 2023 to replace 'gamble responsibly' and must accompany all gambling advertisements that appear online, as well as on TV and radio.

Classification: on 29 March 2023, the Government announced proposed improvements to the National Classification Scheme to address concerns about gambling-like content in video games. This includes a proposed mandatory minimum classification of R18+ for games that contain simulated gambling and M for games that contain paid loot boxes.

Continued progress towards strengthening Australia's legislative framework and ensuring harm reduction measures are in place is essential before there is any consideration of legalising a new gambling service in Australia.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Higher Education Contribution Scheme
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4332 on the legitimacy of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) system.

When a student applies for enrolment in a Commonwealth supported place (CSP) or to access the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP), they are required to submit an electronic Commonwealth Assistance Form (eCAF) with their higher education provider.

The eCAF includes a declaration that the student has read and understood the associated HELP booklet, published by the Government. This measure seeks to ensure that prospective students are aware of their obligations before accessing the loan. Each booklet contains information on the income-contingent nature of the loan as well as indexation.

The HELP booklets are published annually on the Study Assist website and are linked directly from the eCAF. They are also available at www.studyassist.gov.au/need-more-information/help-publications. Additionally, there are several videos published on the Study Assist website that explain the HELP scheme and how HELP debt repayments work.

The HELP scheme, and the previous HECS, is designed to reduce upfront barriers to education. This lifechanging support has made it possible for millions of Australians to get a university degree and the skills they need for the jobs being created in the future.

A university degree is a valuable investment that has the potential to help a person increase their earning capacity. Today, the average annual income of an individual with a university degree is approximately $30,000 more than the average annual income of someone whose last year of education was Year 12.

I appreciate there may be concerns about cost-of-living pressures and the impact of the rise in student debts due to this year's indexation figure. Indexation plays an important role in ensuring that debts maintain their real value over time and reinforces the long-term financial sustainability of HELP.

The application of indexation is legislated under the Higher Education Support Act 2003. The income-contingent nature of HELP ensures that an individual only repays their HELP debt when they earn over the minimum repayment threshold—$51,550 in 2023-24.
An individual who earns below the minimum repayment threshold is not required to make any repayments, and the Australian Government accepts that some people may never be able to do so.

The Australian Government has taken steps to address the impact of cost-of-living pressures in the recent Budget. The $14.6 billion cost-of-living package includes increasing the rate of JobSeeker, Youth allowance, Austudy, ABSTUDY and rental assistance which will help students pay for things like food and rent. More information is available https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/sites/default/files/2023-05/budget-2023-24-may-services-australia-2.pdf.

It may also interest students to know that the Government is committed to delivering an Australian Universities Accord (the Accord), a 12-month review of Australia's higher education system which is considering a range of issues including the importance of affordability and access for students.

The Accord Interim Report was released on 19 July 2023, and proposed priority actions for Government to consider. The Government will act on the five immediate actions identified in the report ahead of the Accord Panel's Final Report. Submissions to the interim report are now open.

The Accord Panel will provide a final report to the Government in December 2023, containing a series of recommendations and targets. Further information about the Accord and a copy of the Interim Report can be found on the Department of Education's website at www.education.gov.au/australian-universities-accord.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Motorsport
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 July 2023 regarding petition EN4392 you presented in the House of Representatives on the establishment of a National Motorsport Strategy.

Motorsport Australia is recognised by the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) as a National Sporting Organisation (NSO) covering a range of motorsport disciplines. As an NSO, Motorsport Australia is considered the pre-eminent body for motorsports in Australia and is responsible for developing any new strategies as relevant to their sport.

The Government, through the ASC, continues to develop sector wide strategies that provide guidance and support to all recognised sports. This includes the development of the National Sport Plan, Australia's 2032+ High Performance Sports Strategy, and the current development of a sector co-designed National Sport Participation Strategy.

In the 2023-24 financial year, Motorsport Australia received $200,000 from the Government, through the ASC, to support participation growth. Motorsport Australia are planning to use a portion of this funding to further build on their successful Girls on Track Program which will now include Inspire, Pathways, and Experience programs. Their Women's Introduction to Motorsport pilot program was successfully held in 2022-2023 and they are currently planning to hold more events in 2023-2024.

In May 2023, Motorsport Australia released their latest strategic plan for the period of 2023-2025. The ASC's participation growth funding will support one of the key initiatives in their plan to 'Expand and increase participation and engagement in motorsport'.
More information on Motorsport Australia's strategic plan is available at www.motorsport.org.au/about.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport. Ms Wells
Aged Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email dated 7 November 2022, received by my office on 25 July 2023, concerning Petition EN4403 which seeks increased support for carers of the elderly.

The Australian Government acknowledges the important contribution carers make to the lives of those they care for and supports their efforts and dedication. This is demonstrated through the range of payments, programs and services provided by the Government to support carers in their caring role.

Carer Payment provides income support to carers of people with disability, a medical condition and those who are frail from age. As a pension payment, it is paid at the highest legislated rate in the social security system, currently $1,064 per fortnight for singles or $802 for each member of a couple. Pension payments are indexed in March and September each year, to ensure payments keep pace with the cost of living, with next increase on 20 September 2023.

Qualification for Carer Payment includes a Pensioner Concession Card, which entitles carers to subsidised prescription medicines and some state-based concessions, such as discounts on motor vehicle registration, electricity, gas and rates. Carers who rent in the private rental market may also receive assistance though Commonwealth Rent Assistance, with maximum rates increasing by 15 per cent (plus indexation) on 20 September.

Most Carer Payment carers also receive Carer Allowance, a $144.80 fortnightly supplement to assist towards the costs a carer may incur, plus the annual $600 Carer Supplement. Carer Allowance is also available to other individuals who provide qualifying care.

The Carer Gateway is also there to provide support and information to assist carers to access individually tailored services within their local area. Services include support planning, targeted financial support packages, counselling, peer support, information and advice, and where necessary, access to emergency respite. To discuss supports suitable for their situation, carers can contact Carer Gateway by calling 1800 422 737 or online at www.carergateway.gov.au.

There are other government funded programs that support older Australians to maintain their independence and remain living at home within their communities. These supports can also benefit carers by reducing some of the care the carer provides.

The Commonwealth Home Support Programme assists frail, older people aged 65 years and over (or 50 years and over for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people) who need help with daily tasks due to their functional limitations. For older people with complex support needs, the Home Care Package can provide a coordinated package of services tailored to meet an individual's assessed care needs. Access is to these programs is through My Aged Care, who can be contacted on 1800 200 422 or via the website at www.myagedcare.gov.au.

Support to navigate aged care services is available through the National Aged Care Advocacy Program (NACAP), delivered nationally through the Older Person's Advocacy Network. The NACAP helps older people and their carers to understand and exercise their aged care rights, seek aged care services that suit their needs and find solutions to issues they may be experiencing. NACAP can be contacted on 1800 700 600 or via their website at www.opan.com.au.

A number of measures in the 2023-24 Budget to support Australians with cost of living pressures may also benefit carers. This includes help with power bills (including for concession-card holders) through the Energy Bill Relief Fund, historic investments in Medicare to incentivise bulk-billing and cheaper medicines.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me, and I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

Child Care
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 to the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, Minister for Social Services, in relation to Child Care Subsidy (CCS) for grandparents who look after their grandchildren. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for reply.

The Australian Government recognises the valuable role that grandparents play in caring for their grandchildren either to support parents' workforce responsibilities or to provide care on a temporary or full-time basis when parents are unable or unwilling to do so.

CCS is a payment to ensure early childhood education and care (ECEC) is affordable for families and designed to assist parents afford the genuine costs of commercial child care. It is not designed to subsidise child care that would otherwise occur within a typical extended family.

The Government also continues to support grandparents who help their families in difficult circumstances by being the principal carer of their grandchild(ren). Where a grandparent becomes the principal carer of their grandchild(ren), they are exempt from the CCS activity test and eligible for up to 100 hours of subsidised child care per fortnight, at a rate of up to 100 per cent of ECEC fees.

Prior to July 2018, the Registered Care program paid up to $35.95 per week to registered carers, including grandparents in some cases, for providing child care. However, the Productivity Commission, in its 2014 Inquiry into Childcare and Early Childhood Learning, concluded that the case for subsidising informal care arrangements such as grandparents caring for grandchildren was not strong given there were no educational qualifications or quality standards required for carers.

While Registered Care is no longer available, the Government understands the cost-of-living pressures that families are facing and has committed to reducing the cost of ECEC to support working families get ahead. That is why from 10 July 2023, the Government increased the CCS rate for around 96 per cent of Australian families using ECEC earning less than $530,000—around 1.2 million families.

The changes to the CCS are just one of a number of measures the Government is taking to support families and invest in the early years to help all Australian children have the best possible start in life.

The Government has directed the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to hold an inquiry into ECEC prices. The ACCC released its ECEC price inquiry interim report on 5 July 2023. The interim report provides early insight into the ACCC's investigations into prices, affordability and the market for ECEC. The ACCC will continue to conduct detailed sector analysis, gathering information about the cost of providing ECEC, and closely watching the pricing behaviour of providers as CCS increases take effect.

This will help shape the ACCC's September consultation paper which will include analysis of costs, the effectiveness of price regulation mechanisms and potential draft findings and recommendations. The ACCC's final report will be delivered to the Government by 31 December 2023.

The Government has also commissioned a comprehensive Productivity Commission (the Commission) inquiry into Australia's ECEC system to help chart a course for universal, affordable ECEC. The inquiry will make recommendations to support affordable, accessible, equitable and high-quality ECEC that reduces barriers to workforce participation and supports children's learning and development. The Commission will release a draft report in November 2023 and provide a final report to the Government by 30 June 2024.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Early Childhood Education, Dr Aly (Petition No. EN4430)
Inland Rail
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 8 July 2023 regarding petition EN4453 which requests the House of Representatives change the proposed Inland Rail line to bypass Wagga Wagga. I understand your email was not received on the date it was sent due to a technical error but I nonetheless apologise for the delay in responding.

On 6 April 2023, the Australian Government released its response to the independent review of Inland Rail undertaken by Dr Keny Schott AO. The government has agreed or agreed in-principle to all 19 recommendations presented in Dr Schott's report. The report and government response are available at www.inlandrail.gov.au.

Key findings of the review include that the route selected for Inland Rail is fit-for-purpose and that where it bisects a regional town, appropriate mitigations to limit noise and vibration and maintain cross town traffic flows should be implemented. With respect to Wagga Wagga, Dr Schott found that no immediate change should be made to the Inland Rail route, but bypass options should be investigated in the future should rail traffic significantly increase.

I can confirm that the NSW Government has requested the Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) prepare a Preferred Infrastructure Report (PIR) to address concerns raised in submissions following the public exhibition of the draft Albury to Illabo Environmental Impact Statement (EIS).

The NSW Government has specifically directed ARTC to undertake further noise, vibration and traffic assessments in relation to Wagga Wagga to ensure that its proposed mitigations will address any such impacts to the town. Once completed, the PIR will be submitted to the NSW Government for acceptance as part of the regulated EIS approval process.

The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts will engage with the Department of Finance and ARTC to put in place oversight and monitoring oftrain movements, forecasts and impacts on communities as Inland Rail is delivered. This will inform decisions on future transport corridors.
I thank the Wagga Wagga community for bringing their concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Public Holiday: Queen Elizabeth II
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter dated 8 November 2022 regarding Petition EN4468 which requests that the Australian Government establish a national public holiday to honour the late Queen Elizabeth II's memory. I understand there was an administrative error in the distribution of your letter. I sincerely apologise for the delay in responding.

The declaration of public holidays is the responsibility of the states and territories. Where a public holiday has been recognised nationally this has been agreed between the Prime Minister, State Premiers and Territory Chief Ministers.

Many Australians share the view that Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II was an extraordinary woman, not only for her 70 year service to the Commonwealth, but for the significant charitable work she carried out during her reign. Through her steadfast support for charities, Queen Elizabeth served as a role model for the whole Commonwealth and leaves a formidable legacy for the positive impact she had on Australia and the Commonwealth.
A National Memorial Service was held at Australian Parliament House on 22 September 2022, and broadcast to the nation.

The day of the National Memorial Service was observed as a National Day of Mourning, and a one-off public holiday was held to allow the nation to view or attend the service, and provide an opportunity for all Australians to reflect on the life and service of Queen Elizabeth.
The Australian Government is not pursuing further public holidays to commemorate the life of Her Late Majesty.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Australian Taxation Office
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4657 regarding the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) handling of Goods and Services Tax (GST) liabilities. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The GST is a consumption tax, which means, in economic terms, that the tax is charged on consumption transactions of households. GST is collected on the value added by each business in the production and distribution chain and then remitted to the ATO by businesses. This is achieved by taxing the full value of a business' sales and allowing the business a credit (called an input tax credit) for GST incurred on its acquisitions, with only the net amount being remitted. Input tax credits ensure GST is only collected on the value added by each business in the production and distribution chain and effectively reduces the GST on business inputs to zero. Under this framework, GST liabilities reflect tax that has been charged by businesses to households.

GST liabilities generally reflect what has been reported by the business through self-assessment. However, the ATO may make amendments where it becomes aware that the information reported in the Business Activity Statement (BAS) may be incorrect. Businesses can also review, and correct information previously reported on a BAS, provided it falls within a four-year period of review. Where businesses think that the ATO has made an error in processing their BAS, they can contact the ATO to raise the issue and seek an amendment.

If businesses are dissatisfied with the ATO's assessment resulting in a GST liability, they can exercise their review rights under Part IVC of the Tax Administration Act 1953. This includes lodging an objection to 'the ATO, as well as seeking external review rights with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or Federal Court of Australia where the taxpayer has already lodged an objection.

The ATO also provides taxpayers with assistance when addressing their tax liabilities, particularly when taxpayers find it difficult to repay their tax debts in full and on time. Where a GST liability arises, businesses may enter a payment arrangement which allows businesses to make repayments by instalments, including interest for late payments, over a fixed period until the balance is cleared. Businesses can contact the ATO to find out more about how the payment arrangements and other assistance available to their individual circumstances.

The ATO administers GST on behalf of the States and Territories. As the ATO 1s an independent statutory body that regulates taxes, the Government is not able to influence its administrative decisions. This extends to the ATO's communications to businesses and other taxpayers as well as the ATO's resourcing decisions.

The ATO communicates the outcome of all small business compliance activities in writing. These finalisation letters include the contact details of the relevant compliance area and provide information on available objection and review rights to the decision. Where the compliance action results in a debt, specific information is included outlining this and the options available to the taxpayer to address the outstanding amount.
Generally, small businesses will also receive a notice of assessment which will include any amounts owing and a statement of account.

The petition raises concerns regarding the ATO's complaints processes. The ATO's website indicates that they aim to resolve complaints within fifteen business days. However, due to current increased volumes of work, the ATO has acknowledged that complaints may take up to thirty business days to resolve. Where taxpayers are not satisfied with the ATO's handling of their complaint or complaint outcome, taxpayers can contact the Inspector-General of Taxation and Taxation Ombudsman.

Neither the House nor Parliament conduct audits on the ATO. The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) undertakes audits and provides independent reports and advice to Parliament, the Australian Government, and the community. The ANAO receives requests for audit from members and senators of the Parliament which may assist in considering what to include in the ANAO's audit work program. More information may need to be obtained before such a request can be made.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Jones
Digital Platforms: Standards
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the Minister for Communications, the Hon Michelle Rowland MP, concerning Petition EN4697 on introducing legislation for companies to enable consumers to unsubscribe to their services by the most simple and accessible means reasonably practicable. As this falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence was referred to me for response.

In February 2020 the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) was directed to conduct an inquiry into markets for the supply of digital platform services. Multiple reports published as part of the inquiry have highlighted the potential for an unfair trading prohibition to address concerns outlined in the petition, for example, by prohibiting unfair subscription trap behaviours which make it significantly more difficult for a consumer to end a subscription than to sign up.

At a meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory Consumer Affairs Ministers in Adelaide in September 2022, Consumer Ministers agreed that Commonwealth Treasury would lead public consultation on options to combat unfair trading practices. I have released a Consultation Regulation Impact Statement for public consultation on this matter, and look forward to progressing this important work.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Cybercrime
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 May 2023 regarding petition EN4968 which relates to the retention and protection of personal information by companies. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.
The Australian Government is committed to protecting Australians' personal information and to further strengthening privacy laws.

The Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) regulates the handling of personal information about individuals. Relevant entities are required to take reasonable steps to protect personal info1mation they hold from misuse, interference and loss, as well as unauthorised access, modification or disclosure (Australian Privacy Principle 11). Where an entity no longer needs personal information for any purpose for which the information may be used or disclosed, under the Australian Privacy Principles the entity must take reasonable steps to destroy the information or ensure that it is de-identified.

Recent large-scale data breaches have highlighted the need to update and strengthen our laws to manage the immense amounts of personal info1mation collected about Australians. That is why the Government passed the Privacy Legislation Amendment (Enforcement and Other Measures) Act 2022 which significantly increases maximum penalties under the Privacy Act, and provides the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) with enhanced enforcement powers. The passage of this law sends a clear message that entities must take privacy, security and data protection seriously.

The Government released the Attorney-General's Department's Review of the Privacy Act earlier this year, which will info1m future reforms to ensure the Act remains fit-for-purpose, supports an innovative economy and responds to new challenges in the digital age. The review included extensive consultation over a two-year period across industry, government and the general public.
The Government is currently considering proposals put forward in the Review, including to:

reinforce the existing requirement for entities to only collect what is reasonably necessary and to destroy personal information when it is no longer required. This will be supported through enhanced OAIC guidelines for entities on the steps they should take to destroy or de-identify personal information to meet their obligations;
ensure that entities determine, and periodically review, the period of time for which they retain personal information;
enhance the Notifiable Data Breaches scheme so that, when a data breach occurs, quick action can be taken to minimise harm to affected individuals; and

provide a right for individuals to request erasure of their personal information; a right to request access to, and seek an explanation about, their personal information held by an entity; and a right for individuals to object to the collection, use or disclosure of their personal information by an entity.

Further to this, the Review proposes significant reforms to strengthen the enforcement of the Privacy Act including new civil penalties and new powers for the lnfo1mation Commissioner in relation to investigations, public inquiries and determinations. The Government's response to the recommendations and a plan for implementation will be released later this year.

In addition to privacy reforms, the Australian Government recognises the need to improve our national resilience to cyber threats and properly address the consequences of cyber incidents. The Australian Government will lead a nationally coordinated approach to building Australia's cyber security and resilience and lifting Australia's capability to meet the evolving challenges of cyberspace. To achieve this, the Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon. Clare O'Neil MP, has announced the development of the 2023-2030 Australian Cyber Security Strategy (the Strategy) which will outline the Australian Government's long-term vision for the future of Australian cyber security and the steps required to get there.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Gambling Advertising
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 May 2023 regarding Petition EN4998.

The signatories of this petition have expressed concern regarding the levels of gambling losses and harm experienced by Australians and are calling for the House of Representatives to ban gambling advertising on all Australian media.

Advertising regulation in Australia is intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards. The Government recognises the imp01iance of gambling promotions being presented in a responsible manner.
The Government is committed to guaranteeing online gambling takes place under a robust legislative framework with strong consumer protections.

On 28 June 2023, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs released the final report from its inquiry into online gambling and its impacts on those experience gambling harm. The comprehensive report makes 31 recommendations around consistent national consumer protections, online gambling regulation, and gambling adve1iising.

I have been clear in saying that the status quo of gambling advertising cannot continue and that any reform will need to address all platforms. The Government is currently considering the report and will respond to the recommendations in due course. More information about the inquiry, including the Committee's final report, can be found at:
.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/House/Social_Policy_and_Legal_Affairs/Onlinegamblingimpacts.

Reforms taken forward from the inqui1y will complement work the Government has already put in place to reduce gambling harms, including committing to ban credit cards for online wagering, progressing classification reform to protect children from simulated gambling in computer games, and implementing new evidence-based taglines to replace 'gamble responsibly' that convey the risks and potential harm from online wagering.

On 21 August 2023, the Government launched BetStop, the national self-exclusion register for online wagering. The register allows individuals to self-exclude from Australian licensed wagering services (online and telephone) for a period of 3 months to a lifetime. BetStop is the tenth and final element of the National Consumer Protection Framework for online wagering to be implemented.
For more information on these measures, please visit the following webpages:
Credit card ban—minister.infrastructure.gov.au/rowland/media-release/albanese-government-will-ban-credit-cards-online-wagering
Classification reform—infrastructure.gov.au/have-your-say/proposed-new-mandatory-minimum-classifications-gambling-content-computer-games
Consistent gambling messaging—dss.gov.au/communities-and-vulnerable-people-programs-services-gambling/information-for-online-wagering-providers
BetStop—www.betstop.gov.au
I have enclosed some additional information regarding the current gambling advertising restrictions.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the info1mation will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
Enc. Current gambling advertising restrictions
Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.
Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulat01y codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

There are rules that relate to the content and scheduling of advertisements, including gambling advertisements. Generally, the codes prohibit gambling advertising during programs that are principally directed to children.
The Commercial TV Code also prohibits gambling adve1iisements:
during General (G), Preschool (P) or Children's (C) rated programs broadcast between:
6.00 am and 8.30 am, 4.00 pm and 7.00 pm; and
during any program that is broadcast between 5.00 am and 8.30 pm and which is principally directed to children.
These prohibitions do not apply during news, current affairs or sports programs broadcast in those time periods.

Further limits apply to gambling advertisements and the promotion of odds shown during live spo1iing events broadcast on commercial television, commercial radio, subscription television and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). For example, no gambling advertising or promotion of odds is allowed during play and no promotion of odds is allowed during breaks in play (such as halftime). More information about these restrictions is available on the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) website at acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-live-sports-broadcasts.

The codes of practice also include procedures for dealing with complaints. In the first instance, a complaint must be submitted to the relevant broadcaster. A complaint may be referred to ACMA if a broadcaster does not provide a response within 60 days or if the response provided is considered to be inadequate. Copies of the codes of practice are available on ACMA's website at acma.gov.au/industry-codes-practice.

Broadcasting co-regulato1y codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact the relevant peak industry body to raise their concerns, and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes. The contact details for the commercial broadcasters are available at: freetv.com.au/contact-us/network-contacts/.

Additionally, the Broadcasting Services (Online Content Service Provider Rules) 2018 (Online Rules) restricts the showing of gambling promotions during online streams of live sporting events. These contain gambling promotions restrictions that are, to the extent possible, similar to those that the broadcasting industry codes impose on the broadcast of live sporting events. More information about the Online Rules is available on ACMA's website at acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-sport-streamed-over-internet.
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Wages
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 22 May 2023 regarding petition number EN5023, which proposes a ban on junior rates of pay.

The Fair Work Commission can consider applications to vary modem awards where an applicant believes that the classifications and remuneration paid to employees no longer reflect the value of the work being performed by the employees. Applications to vary modem awards can be made by various parties as outlined on the Fair Work Commission's website at www.fwc.gov.au.
Thank you for writing to me seeking consideration of this important issue and petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Gun Control
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding Petition EN5026, which expressed concern about the proposed implementation of a National Firearms Register (Register). I welcome the opportunity to provide a response to this petition for consideration by the Committee.
While Australia has some of the strongest firearms laws in the world, the Government recognises that continuous commitment is required to keep the community safe.

Following the tragic deaths of two police officers and a member of the public on 12 December 2022 in Wieambilla, National Cabinet committed to improving the way firearms information is shared to keep police and the community safe.
To this end, National Cabinet tasked Police Ministers and I with developing options for a Register. All jurisdictions acknowledge that improvements are required to better:
trace firearms across interstate and international borders
provide accurate and timely information to police on firearms ownership and risks, and
detect the movement of firearms to the illicit market.

Work on the Register is ongoing in close consultation with states and territories and with input from industry stakeholders. The Government is committed to ensuring that any proposed register will operate in accordance with established safeguards to protect information and privacy.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Employment: Remuneration
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding a petition for an amendment to the Fair Work Act 2009 (Fair Work Act) to regulate job advertisements (EN5030), presented to the Standing Petitions Committee on the same date. I have considered the issues raised through the petition and the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations has consulted the Treasury, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) and the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO).

Job advertisements provide businesses the opportunity to promote the benefits of their jobs to attract the right candidates. The current regulatory framework allows businesses the freedom to so while also preventing potential candidates from being misled.

Currently, under Section 31 of the Australian Consumer Law (ACL), misleading conduct relating to offering employment is prohibited. This means that employers must not mislead those seeking employment about any matter relating to employment, including the availability, nature, terms or conditions of employment.

The ACL is enforced by the ACCC, and state and territory consumer law regulators, under a 'one law, multiple regulators' model. Consumers and businesses can report misleading conduct relating to employment to the ACCC or to their local consumer protection agency.

However only a court can decide whether Section 31 of the ACL has been breached. If a court determines there has been a contravention, it can impose pecuniary penalties or make other orders, such as remedial orders or an injunction.
Affected consumers also have a private right of action under the ACL. They can apply to a court to seek damages against a business that engages in misleading conduct in relation to employment.

Employers also have an ongoing responsibility to classify and pay their workers correctly or risk being non-compliant with their workplace obligations. The FWO is the independent regulator responsible for providing advice, education and assistance about Australian workplace laws and impartially enforcing those laws. The FWO's guidance on job advertisements provides useful information on prohibited job advertisements and can be found at www.fairwork.gov.au/starting-employment/job-ads. In2022 the Government amended the Fair Work Act to ensure that job advertisements cannot include pay rates that would breach the Fair Work Act or a fair work instrument such as an award or enterprise agreement. This means that job advertisements cannot include pay rates that undercut employees' minimum entitlements.

As highlighted by the petition, the Government amended the Fair Work Act to prohibit pay secrecy clauses in employment contracts, improving transparency in workplaces. Pay secrecy clauses included in new employment contracts since 7 December2022 will have no effect. Furthermore, from 7 June2023 these clauses became prohibited and their inclusion in employment contracts will attract penalties. The key aim of this reform is to improve gender pay equity and reduce the risk of discrimination, such as where two people are paid differently for doing the same job, by removing legal prohibitions on workers discussing their own pay. This gives employees the right to disclose their pay to others if they want to, as well ask other employees about their remuneration.

Through these laws as enforced by the ACCC, the courts and the FWO, the Australian Government is striving to strike the right balance to ensure job advertisements are fair, without misleading potential candidates, while providing businesses with the opportunity to promote their place of work.
Thank you for writing to me regarding these important issues and the petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke

subdebateinfo.title: Central West New South Wales: Floods

p.span: Central West New South Wales: Floods
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 20 June 2023, enclosing Petition EN5065, with 9 signatures, proposing a resilience package is legislated for Cabonne, New South Wales (NSW).

I know first-hand from my visits to flood-impacted communities across NSW and Queensland—including communities in Cabonne and across the Central West—that the flooding events that began in November 2021 and continued through the first half of last year have had devastating effects on people. That is why the Commonwealth has committed a significant amount of support across both states.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for responding to disasters and providing immediate assistance to impacted communities. The Australian Government supports the states with the costs of providing relief and recovery assistance to communitie5 through the jointly-funded Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements (DRFA).

Under the DRFA, states and territories determine the type and level of assistance to make available following a disaster. Importantly, these jurisdictions are not bound by the DRFA, and can make available whatever assistance they deem necessary, regardless of whether it is eligible for cost sharing under the DRFA. This recognises that states and territories are best placed to identify the type and level of assistance to make available following a disaster, in accordance with their responsibility for disaster management.

In response to the severe weather and flooding from September 2022 onwards, the Australian and New South Wales (NSW) Governments made a range of recovery assistance available under the DRFA across impacted Local Government Areas, including Cabonne. Information on available recovery assistance can be found at www.disasterassist.gov.au.

Extraordinary recovery measures under the DRFA, beyond the immediate supports provided like emergency payments and support for council clean ups, must be requested by a state premier or chief minister. These packages are considered by the Prime Minister for agreement.

The Resilient Homes funds in the Northern Rivers ofNSW and in Queensland were both approved by the Prime Minister following a request from the respective state governmen:s. This included an agreement by both states to equally cost share the assistance. These measures are not legislated by the Australian Parliament.

The NSW Reconstruction Authority (NSWRA) is the body responsible for disaster recovery in NSW. Officials from the National Emergency Management Agency have relayed the terms ofPetition EN5065 to the NSWRA for consideration.

The Commonwealth recognises the importance in investing in disaster resilience and mitigation, to ensure communities are better prepared for the natural disasters they will face in the future. That's why we have also committed up to $1 billion in Commonwealth funding over five years for our flagship Disaster Ready Fund, to fund disaster resilience and mitigation projects across the country. The first round ofthe Disaster Ready Fund, announced earlier this year, included funding for the Cabonne Council to help deliver risk reduction equipment, a critical evacuation centre and early warning systems for improved disaster response.
The Australian Government continues to work closely with the NSW Government to ensure necessary assistance and additional support is provided to affected communities.
Thank you again for bringing Petition EN5065 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Emergency Management, Senator Watt
Film and Video Game Classification
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 1 August 2023 to the Hon Tony Burke MP, Minister for the Arts, about petition EN5113 regarding the request from petitioners to review and limit the proliferation of Indian Hindutva films, such as The Kerala Story and The Kashmir Files. Your email was referred to me, as classification policy falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The National Classification Scheme (the Scheme) regulates the classification and availability of films, computer games and certain publications within Australia. The Scheme is a co-operative scheme between the federal, state and territory governments. Under the Scheme, classification is a federal government responsibility, and enforcement of the Scheme is a state and territory responsibility.

Under the Scheme, the Classification Board (the Board) makes decisions about films, computer games and certain publications. The Board is a statutory body, independent of government. When making decisions, the Board applies the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Act), the National Classification Code (the Code) and the relevant classification guidelines. The Act, the Code and the guidelines can be found at www.classification.gov.au. The guidelines are jointly agreed to by the Commonwealth and state and territory governments.
The Act states that, when classifying content, the Board is to consider:
(a) the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults; and
(b) the literary, artistic or educational merit (if any) of the publication, film or computer game; and
(c) the general character of the publication, film or computer game, including whether it is of a medical, legal or scientific character; and
(d) the persons or class of persons to or amongst whom it is published or is intended or likely to be published.

The Code provides that classification decisions should give effect, as far as possible, to the principles that adults should be able to read, hear and see what they want, while recognising that minors should be protected from material likely to harm them, and all Australians should be protected from offensive, unsolicited material as well as the need to take account of community concerns about depictions that condone or incite violence, particularly sexual violence, and the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner.

The classification categories for film are: G (General), PG (Parental Guidance), M (Mature), MA 15+ (Mature Accompanied), R 18+ (Restricted), X 18+ (Restricted) and RC (Refused Classification). The type of content permissible in each classification is described in the Guidelines for the Classification of Films (Film Guidelines) and the consideration of impact and context are essential principles in the use of the Film Guidelines. When classifying a film, the Board assesses the impact of six classifiable elements: themes, violence, sex, language, drug use, and nudity.

On 10 March 2022, the Board classified The Kashmir Files, R 18+ with consumer advice of 'High Impact themes and violence'. The Board noted that The Kashmir Files contains high impact themes and violence, including themes of brutal repression, which are, at times, inextricably linked within the narrative of the film. A film classified R18+ may not be sold or exhibited to persons under 18 years.

On 9 May 2023, the Board classified The Kera/a Story, MA 15+ with consumer advice of 'Strong themes, violence and sexual violence'. The Board noted that The Kera/a Story contains strong themes and violence, including sexual violence, which are justified by context and inextricably linked through the narrative of the film. A film classified MA 15+ is considered unsuitable for persons under 15 years and is a legally restricted category.

In certain circumstances, a person may apply to the Classification Review Board for a review of a classification decision. Information about applying for a review is at: www.classification.gov.au/for-industry/appIy-for-classification/apply-for-review-classification-decision.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Macquarie Point Stadium
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 1 August 2023 regarding the petition to fund a stadium at Macquarie Point, Hobart (EN5143).

The Australian Government is committed to partnering with state, territory and local governments to facilitate urban renewal in Australia's growing cities and regions to improve liveability, productivity and enhance amenity. The Australian Government's $240 million investment in the Macquarie Point precinct will help unlock the potential of the precinct while generating social and economic activity. This investment is an opportunity to ensure all existing and proposed users respect the history of the site and region, upgrades to Macquarie Wharves and the delive1y of more social, affordable or essential worker housing.
The Tasmanian Government is developing a refreshed precinct plan for the site that will

be informed by community engagement and consultation to consider the wide range of views and opportunities for this site. I encourage signatories of this petition to share their views about the precinct by visiting the website, www.macpoint.com/precinctplan.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Remuneration and Entitlements
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding Petition EN5150—Wages linked to the Consumer Price Index or Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cash rate.

The Government understands that many households are doing it tough from cost-of-living pressures and higher interest rates. Inflation peaked at the end of last year and has begun to moderate, with the RBA signalling higher wages growth for the rest of the year.

Minimum and award wages are set each year by the independent Fair Work Commission's Expert Panel for Annual Wage Reviews. In making its decision, the Expert Panel is required to take into account the performance and competitiveness of the economy, the likely impact on business, and relative living standards and the needs of the low paid. In this year's Annual Wage Review, the Expert Panel awarded an above-inflation increase to the National Minimum Wage of 8.6 per cent and increased award wages by 5.75 per cent. These increases, the highest on record, took effect from 1 July 2023.

In addition to this guaranteed minimum wage for all employees, wages may be set under enterprise agreements or individual arrangements. The Government is working to ensure workers have access to a stronger workplace bargaining system that will help lift wages and improve job security. For instance, the recent Secure Jobs, Better Pay reforms removed barriers to single-enterprise bargaining and provide more options for business and employees to make multi-enterprise agreements.
Thank you for writing to me seeking consideration of this important issue and petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence dated 1 August 2023, concerning petition reference EN5165.

The Albanese Government understands access to safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians. The Government is committed to an ambitious housing agenda which will boost the supply of all housing to address the cost of housing whether you are buying or renting.

The National Rental Affordability Scheme (NRAS, the Scheme) is an Australian Government affordable housing initiative, delivered in partnership with state and territory governments which was terminated by the former Federal Liberal Government in 2014. There are dwellings remaining in the Scheme which will continue to offer reduced rents until 2026. It was announced in the 2014-15 Budget, there will be no further funding rounds or new allocations of NRAS incentives beyond those currently allocated in the Scheme and held by approved participants.

At the conclusion of the Scheme, NRAS dwellings will remain subject to all relevant state and territory government tenancy laws, with respect to lease agreements and rental increases. Some NRAS allocations are held by endorsed charities, which includes Community Housing Providers (CHPs). Some CHPs may continue to offer reduced rents.

In regards to the request of the petition in relation to tenancy rights, while the regulation of residential tenancies, agreements and rental pricing, is a matter for state and territory governments, the Albanese Labor Government continues to work with all tiers of government to deliver better housing outcomes.

At National Cabinet in August this year the Commonwealth, state and territory governments committed to A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia. This included developing a nationally consistent framework including a requirement for genuine reasonable grounds for eviction, moving towards limiting rental increases to once a year and phasing in minimum rental standards.
These changes will make a tangible impact for the almost one-third of Australian households who rent.

The Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.

These housing challenges didn't happen overnight and cannot be solved by one government alone. As mentioned, the Albanese Government is working with the states and territories and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
These measures are in addition to the work we've already started.

The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund to support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years has, for the second time, been introduced into the Parliament. We've reintroduced this important legislation because we want to use every process available to ensure tens of thousands of new homes are built for Australians.
The Albanese Government will deliver the Help to Buy scheme with state and territory governments to help thousands of Australians into home ownership.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility, has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in social and affordable rental homes, with projects already under construction as a result of this funding.

The National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation's liability cap has been increased by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator.
We've delivered the largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rate.
Tax incentives have been provided to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market.

Federal funding of $1.7 billion has been provided for a one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement with States and Territories, including a $67.5 million boost to homelessness funding over the next year.

More than 50,000 Australians have been helped into home ownership through the Home Guarantee Scheme, including more than 6,000 through the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee. The scheme has now been expanded significantly—changes will see friends, siblings, and other family members eligible for joint applications under the First Home Guarantee and the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee.

We've also established an interim National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, while legislation goes through the Parliament to create the Council as an independent body.

In addition, the Albanese Government is developing a National Housing and Homelessness Plan (the Plan) to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

The Plan will be informed by advice provided by the newly established National Housing Supply and Affordability Council and will set out the reforms needed to improve housing and homelessness outcomes across the spectrum, including to make it easier for Australians to buy a home, easier to rent, and reduce homelessness.

The public submission stage of the Plan is now open. If you would like to find out more about consultation activities or encourage involvement from your constituents, you can visit the website at https://engage.dss.gov.au.

Members of the public are now able to participate in submission and consultation activities to share their housing experiences to help inform the Plan. Local governments, not-for-profit and civil society organisations, industry bodies, superannuation funds and other experts in housing, finance and urban development will also take part in consultation activities.
